div.head: THE NEW ACADEMY, OR, THE NEW EXCHANGE.
Act. I.
div.p: IS this the entertainment you promis'd me in the Jovial Merchants house? Is this the great interest you have in his huge hospitality? when by half an hours attendance and intreats, we cannot obtain the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: I wonder at it; Sure some strange disaster has suddenly befallen him. He was, last night the merriest man alive, drank healthes; told tales; sung Catches; Trowle the Bowle; Tosse the Cannykin; and what not! and all for joy, that his sonne, he said, was upon his returne, whom he has not seen these dozen years, since he sent him a little Lad into France, to be bred there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I heard he did so; and that in lieu, by way of
Exchange, he brings up the daughter of the Parisien that breeds his sonne.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But is that daughter so exquisite a creature, as is this Merchant Matchills own whom you so much extoll?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: They are both so equally handsome, and vertuous, that, be their dowries so, and their consents alike, I'll take my choice of crosse and pile for either, with such a friend as thou art.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Troth, and that's friendly spoken, Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: It is so Val. yet not with some policie do I wish thee a fortune: for, insooth. young Gentleman, though I like your person, and some of your qualities, yet by reason of your wants, I finde you something heavy on my purse-strings; and my selfe scarce able to supply you. And, if we faile of good matches, I must even turne you over shortly to the hopes you hoast of in your City-Mystresses and Tradesmens wives—.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace, prythee hold thy peace.
Friend Cash! Is your Master, Mr. Matchill yet at leisure to be seen?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: He much desires, sir, to be held excus'd. 'Tis true that he invited you. His dinner's ready; and his heart welcomes you. But he has met with an unhappy newes to day.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I feard some ill. What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: His only sonne, whom he of late expected home out of France, we hear, is dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: His daughter will prove a bouncing match then.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: That's the impression the heavy newes makes in you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, although my Masters sudden sadnesse shuts him from you. His meat and wine are ready. There are some good company in his Parlour too, Pray stay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are his faire daughter, and the French-borne
Damsel there to be seen?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Both. Pray be pleas'd to enter.
I hope his passionate fit e're you have din'd will be past over. He is not wont to suffer long under the hand of sorrow.
sp.l: 'Tis like that you shall see him ere you go.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: In that faire hope we'll enter and fall to.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: 'Tis like you shall fall short though of your aim
At my young Mystresse, who by this black newes,
Becomes my Masters heire, and so the white
That all the gallant suiters of the City
And Court will level their keen shafts at. Where
Are mine own hopes then, that stood as faire
In competition for her, love as any,
When the great noise of her inheritance,
Shall drown each Lovers tongue, that cannot say,
It is a Lords at least, I rather wish
The young man had not did.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where's my Boykin? my Friskoe? my Delight? my Cash? by what better name can I call thee?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: O me! Master Strigood, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I come to comfort my brother in his sorrow.
His sonne is dead, they say. Ha! Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And he is almost dead with sorrow: Back sir.
The sight of you, that are his sole vexation, will make him mad.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That is my way to cure him.
Madnesse drowns grief in any man.— Probatum.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Good Mr. Strigood depart.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Good Mr. Cash, and Mr. Matchils man.
I'll see your Master. What! deny his brother?
His nowne natural brother? By the surer side too
We tumbled in one Pannier; though we had
Two Rippiers, Sweet sir, I am the elder too
Strigood was in my mother before Matchill
Therefore, because I have spent an estate
And he has got-one, must not I maintain
My self the better man?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Yes: if you had the wherewithal.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, you had been as good ha' held your tongue.
Lend me some money Cash.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I have no money, sir, but what's my Masters.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Whose money, sir, was that you played last night.
Among the Knights and Braveries at the ordinary?
Gold by the handfuls, Cash! Lend me two pieces.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Speak lower, sir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me three pieces, Cash.
Before I speak too loud, whose money's that
You use to weare abroad at Feasts and Revels
In silver lace and satten; though you wait
At home in simple Serge, or broad-cloth, sir.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Be not so loud, I pray.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me five pieces.
I shall grow louder else. Who payes your Barber?
I mean not for your Prentice pig-hair'd cut
Your weare at home here; but your Periwigs;
Your locks and Lady-ware that dangle in 'em,
Like straws in the bush natural of a Bedlem?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: What mean you Mr. Strygood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I mean ten pieces now; I'll go no lesse. Do not I know your haunts?—

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You may; you train'd one to 'em

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Do not I know your our leaps, and vagaries?
Your tiring houses, where you shift your self,
Your privy lodgings, for your trunks and punks?
Your midnight walks and meetings? Come, the money.
And, heark thee, though thou modest my brother by't.
I'll keep thy councel: thou shalt finde me virtuous.
I want, he gives me nothing; and thou canst not
Do him better service, then relieve his brother.

sp.speaker: Cash:
sp.l: I am in; and must, to hide my old faults, do
Like an ill Painter, lawbe 'em o're with new.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Quickly. I shall grow loud again else Cash.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Sir, I am in your hands, here are ten pieces.
I hope you will not thank my Master for 'em.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: No; no for all he has that comes through thy hands.
My nimble Cash; and from his I am sure,
Though I were starving, I should finger nothing.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Will you go now?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I'll see him e're I go,
And dine, if there be meat i'th' house. What eate's
Are there within I'll draw a knife among 'em.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: This desperate old Russian, would undo me,
But he hopes to waste his brother by me.
He has spent himself to beggery; and would fall so,
But that he has pernicious fire in's brain,
That raging spreads to ruine others with him.
I must beware of him,
Is she come too?
Then 'tis deereed, my Master must, from sorrow, suffer in madnesse.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go home Ephraim.
And have a care you suffer not my boy
To Straggle forth 'mong his unhappy play-mates,
For fear of mischief.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: It shall be my care.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What do you lock up my brother, ha?—

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: H' has lock't himself up, Madam; and will suffer
None to come at him, till his sorrowful fit
Be somewhat over.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: not's own Sister, ha?—

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Nor his half brother neither: yet he's here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is he here, ha? That Strygood? Is he here?
Hang him old reprobate. And beshrew thy heart,
For a young varlet, to call him our brother.
It is no marvel, if my brother Matchil
Lock up himself, and such a wickednesse
Be in his house, as is that Strygood, ha—
Let him take heed, he comes not in my Nayl reach,
And call me Sister, or my Brother, brother,
Like a debaush'd old Villain, as he is.
O that my husband Nestlecock were alive,
But for three minutes, to send him to
Newgate, if he presume to call me Sister
But I command you in my husbands name,
Who was a Justice, when he liv'd, to thrust him
Out of your Masters doors, my brothers house.
Lest I be sick with the loath'd sight of him.
You will not disobey this, will you, ha?—
If not, why stir you not? ha.—

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I must remove
This fit of hers. There's but one way to do it;
And that's to talk of her white boy, she's fond on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you not send him packing, ha?—

sp.speaker: Cash,
sp.l: First, Madam.
(By your good Ladiships leave) how does your sonne
Sweet Master Nehemiah Nestlecock?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you courteous friend. In truth, last night,
One of my Coach-gueldings fell lame, and I,
By that constrain'd to come afoot,
Was forc'd to leave my boy at home; or else
He had come with me, to have been a comfort
To his sad Uncle: But I would not now
For twice my Gueldings price, my childe were here;
And that foule fiend i'th' house, whose very looks
Would fright him into sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: O good Lady!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I can't so soon forget the fright he took
At seeing the roguish Jugler once eat tow,
And blow it out of's mouth in fire and smoke,
He lay a fourtnight by't.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: That's two yeares since.
And he was then but young, he's now a man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alack a childe; but going in's nineteenth year.
Where's my Neece Joyce?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Within there Madam; so is Gabriella
The French young Gentlewoman to attend you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll stay with them till I may see my brother.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I hope old Strygood, who now on the sudden
Hath slipt her memory, meets her by the eares first.
sp.stage: Enter Matchil, an opeu letter in his hands.
sp.l: But the good minute's come, before I look't for't.
My Master now appears. He looks most sourely
Expressing more of anger then of grief.
I feare, old Strygood was so loud with me,
That he hath over-heard us, and I shall break
Before I am a Freeman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sorrow be gone
And puleing grief away, whilest I take in
A nobler and more manly Passion;
Anger, that may instruct me to revenge.
My childe is lost by treacherous neglect
In that false Frenchman, to whose seeming care
I trusted the chief comfort of my life;
My boy. Nay, read again. 'Tis written, here,
He was grown man:

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: His man, I think, he said.
sp.stage: Cash listens to Matchil, and speaks aside.
sp.l: Does your man trouble you. I do not like that

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And here he writes that in his youthful spring
And heat of spirit, he began to grow
Intemperate and wilde—

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Wilde! Are you there?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Which drew him on to riotous expence—

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And there again, to riotous expence!
'Tis I directly that he's troubled with.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And sometimes into quarrels. What o' that?
In all this he was still mine own. O boy—

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Some slave has writ some fearful information.
Against me, and he hugs and kisses it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And had his Guardian had a feeling care
(Hang his French friendship) over my dear childe,
As I had over his, these youthful follies
Might have been temper'd into manly vertues.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I hear not that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I fall back agen
From my revenge to grief. Away; I will not.
Here's the death-doing point. These slight disorders.
In my young forward sonne (I finde it here)
Were, by his churlish and perfidious Guardian,
Interpreted no lesse then Reptobation,
And, by his ignorant cruelty, so punish'd.
For, here he shuts his eare and door against him:
When suddenly the loose licentious world
Soothes on his youthful, in judicious courage
To imminent destruction; so being engag'd
In a rash quarrel, he in duel fell.
Th' Opponents sword was instrument; yet I inferre.
Lafoy, his Guarcian was his murderer.
Farewel, my boy; and this is the last teare
Thou shalt wring from me. Something I'll do,
Shall shew a fathers love, and valour too.
I'm young enough to draw a sword in France, yet.
But first— Come hither, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Now it comes.

sp.speaker: Mrt.
sp.l: I purpose streight to order my estate
Look that you forthwith perfect my Accompts;
And bring me all my books of debtor and creditor,
Receipts and payments, what you have in wares,
And what in cash, let me inform my self.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: 'Tis as I fear'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll set all right and streight,
All statutes, bonds, bills, and seal'd instruments
That do concern me, I have in my Closet
Or at my Councels, or my Scriveners.
I'll call in them my selfe. Why doest thou look so amaz'dly?
Would'st have me yield a reason? why, I'll tell thee
I mean to make a voyage; and, perhaps,
To settle and proportion out my estate
By Will, before I go. Do you as I command you.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Whatever he pretends, I know his drift:
And, e're I'll be discover'd by my stay;
Being run out, I'll choose to run away.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My daughter in the first place must be car'd for.
I'll make her a good match. My next in blood then,
My Knave-half-brother, and my whole fool-Sister.
But the best is, her Ladiship has enough;
And all I have, in Strygoods hands, were nothing.
Therefore I'll purpose nothing to him. Oh.
The Joy and Torment of my life, at once
Appear to me. I must divide them, thus.
Hence hated issue of my mortal foe
Whom I have foster'd with a Parents Piety
As carefully and dearly as mine own.
While the inhumane cruelty of thy Sire
Has to untimely death expos'd my sonne.
Thank me I kill not thee; so leave my house.
There's French enough in town, that may befriend you.
To pack you o're to Paris; what's your own
Take w'ye, and go. Why cleave you to her so?
Forsake her, cast her off. Are not my words
Of force, but I must use my hands to part ye?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Deare, honour'd father, I beseech you hear me.
In parting us you separate life from me,
And therein act a real crueltie
On me your only childe, sharper then that,
Which you can but pretend done by her father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Durst thou speak so?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I cannot live from her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O monstrous. Pray, your reason. Why not live?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You know, Sir, from our Infancie we have been,
Bred up together, by your tender care
As we had been twin-borne, and equally
Your own; and by a self-same education,
We have grown hitherto, in one affection,
We are both but one body, and one mind,
What Gabriella was, I was, what I, was she.
And, till this haplesse houre, you have enjoyn'd me,
Nay, charg'd me on your blessing, not to arrogate
More of your love unto my self, then her,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That was, 'cause I presum'd her father lov'd,
Or should have lov'd my sonne, your brother.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I never knew brother, or sister, I;
Nor my poor self, but in my Gabrella.
Then blame me not to love her, I beseech you
— Upon me knees.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Th' art knee-deep in rebellion.
Unnatural Gipsie, since thou prov'st my torment
In being the same with her; and hast declar'd
Thy self no more my childe, then she, whom now
I do abhorre, avoid, with her, my sight.
Rise, and be gone, lest thou pull curses on thee
Shall sink thee into earth.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: O rather, Sir.
Let me, 'gainst whom your fury first was bent
Suffer alone the sharpnesse of your vengeance:
And let it not be said ,'cause you surmise,
My father lost your son, that, therefore, you
Have cast away your daughter. Hurl me, rather,
Into the ruthless waves to seek my way;
Or do but take her, hold her in the armes
Of your paternal love, and I'll take flight
To weane her to you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: She cannot, may not leave me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Out of my doors then, with her.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What's the matter? ha—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Such as you cannot mend, deare Lady Sister.
What come you hither with your Ha— for? Ha—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To comfort you, dear brother, if you'll heare me.
Your sonne is dead, they say; and here I finde
Your daughter is rebellious 'gainst; our will.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You speak much comfort, do you not, think you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But is it so Joyce? ha!— I thought you, Joyce,
Would have rejoyc'd your father in obedience, Joyce;
And not afflict him with your stubbornnesse.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O this impertinent woman!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But my brother,
Let me advise you, rather then suffer her
To be an eye-sore to you, put her out,
Where she may learne more duty. If you please
I'll take her home, and shew her how it should be

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes, as you have shewen your Nestlecock, your sonne.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I, there's a childe! Brother, you'l pardon me,
If I aspire in hope, that he shallbe
Your heire, if Joyce miscarry in rebellion.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And therefore you would breed her. How the devil
Works in a covetous woman! Though a foole too.
Your sonne's an Asse; an Ideot; and your self
No better, that have bred him so. Do you tell me
Of your sweet sugar-chop't Nestle cockscombe?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He's fit t' inherit nothing but a place
I'th' Spittle-house, Fools Colledge, yond, at Knights-bridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And did I come to bring thee consolation?
Now let me tell thee, I rejoyce in thy
Just punishment, thy scourge of crosses. Thou,
That for these six years space, until this day,
Hast kept continual feast and jollitie
For thy wives death, who was too good for thee.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Right, for she was my Master, a perpetual
Vexation to me, while she was above-ground
Your Ladiship could not have spoke more comfort to me
Then the remembrance of that shook-off Shackle,
Which now, in my affliction makes me smile,
And were I on her grave, I could cut capers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A further punishment, I prophecie
Grows in the neck of thy leud insolence

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I could e'ne finde in heart to marry again,
In spight, now, of thy witchcraft, my son dead!
My daughter disobedient! and your childe
A very chilblaine. What have I to do
But marry again: all women are not devils,
I may yet get an heire unto my minde.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Art thou here too—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stay, you forget your brother, Mr. Matchil.
You have match'd ill once already; and take heed
You match not worse, your children, though untoward.
And taking of the devillish Shrew, their mother,
Were likely of your own begetting; Yet
Your second wife may bring you a supply
Of heires, but who must get them, first is doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thy impudence amazes me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'm sick at sight of the leud Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: dee cast about for heirs; and have besides
Your daughter here, a brother and a sister?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Call not thy self our brother. He appears
Unkinde to me, but thou insufferable,
I loath to look upon thee.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He has spoke
sp.p: Against her Aunt, her Moon-calf sonne. I'll make her love me best, and presently.
sp.l: Brother, I say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot look upon thee.
Provoke me not to speech, I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Give me leave to speak; Hold you your peace;
Hear but my brotherly advice; and when
Give your consent in silence.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: hum hum, &c.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hear him not.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: Nor you neither, hum— hum— hum.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am not angry with you now; and therefore
I charge you, hear him not.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: hum hum—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: My advice is thus, that for your daughters good.
For mine own good, and for your Sisters good.
And for her sonne, your Nephew's good.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How's that? ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And chiefly for your own good, and the credit
A wise man would desire to hold i'th' world,
Think not of marrying, nor of buying hornes
At the whole value of your whole estate,
But match your daughter while you have the meanes
In your own hands; give her a good round portion,
Here are deserving Gentlemen i'th' house.
Next, think of me your brother, that has spent
In down-right fellowship (heaven knows what
All fraudulent purposes to make any man
A miser or a gainer by't) a faire estate.
And now do want a brotherly supply.
A hundred a year or so: but above all
Fasten your land unto your Sisters sonne.
That hopeful Gentleman, sweet Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: (Mat)
sp.l: hum.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now brother you may hear him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: What though it straggle from the name of Matchil.
Remember yet he is your mothers Grandchilde.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why dee not hear him, brother?—

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: hum.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As I hope
To be a landed man my self,
Had I a thousand yearly, I would leav't him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Trulie, I thank you. Now I'll call you brother.
Y'are a good natur'd Gentleman if you had it.
Come home, and see my sonne.— Will you not hear him? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I need not, nor your selfe. I see you gape
Like monsters that would swallow me alive.
I know your mindes; and I will do mine own.
And, thus it is. Stay, let me stay a little.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Look you how wilde he looks.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He's falling mad.
Stark staring mad,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would he had a wife then,
For nothing else can tame him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So it shall be.
First, I'll be Master of mine own estate.
Next—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Take a wife to master that, and you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Next, you Madamoiselle, (on whom with patience
I cannot look) forsake my house, and suddenly;
Linger not for a man to wait upon you,
But let your black bag guard you, 'tis a fashion
Begun amongst us here by your own Nation.
And if I longer must call you my daughter,
Forsake you her.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: What mine own heart? dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: At your own choice. I can force her departure,
Though not perswade your stay, determine quickly
Either to leave her, and enjoy a father,
Or never more expect a fathers blessing.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Dear, mine own heart, leave me, obey your father.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: It must be to my death then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll be sudden.
Therefore be you as brief in your resolve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, poor hearts. Just so loth
To part was I and my sonne Nehemiah
Today when I came forth.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Neece Joyce, let me
Advise you.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, none of your advices.
Let her advise her self; whilest I impart
To you my next intention; which is thus.
To end your strife for shares in mine estate
I'll venter on a wife: indeed I'll marry

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you so? ha!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes indeed La,—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: If then
You'l estate nothing on me for my life
Give me a see to help you to a wife,
I can, a good one.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll none, Sir, of your good ones.
Besides, Sir, I'm provided.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are not, are you? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let it suffice, I say't, so quit my house.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Shall I expect then nothing?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray sir, do.
'Tis all I can afford you. You have wit,
Yes, you can daunce, tread money out of rushes,
Slight and activity to live upon.
A nimble braine, quick hands and airie heels
To get a living.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Hah.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray fall to practice.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I may, sir, to your cost, if you put off
Your daughter with her Sweet-heart, her Mon Coeur
There, as she calls her. Dear, my Lady Sister;
You see how churlishly this Merchant uses us.
He has forgot, sure, he was borne a Gentleman.
Will you be pleas'd, I speak to you in your eare.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Any way, brother Strigood, Hang him, Nabal,
To warn me out o's house; and not alone,
To turne a stranger from within his gates,
But offer to cast out his childe too, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis about that I'd speak, pray Madam heark you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Noble Mr. Matchil, though we are your meat
Before we saw you you will give us leave
To take our leaves, and thank you ere we part.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: W'have heard your cause of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I have over-past it. Heark ye Gentlemen

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.l: You'l give us leave first to salute the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, if you love me, heare me first.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Your will, Sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Neece, you shall no way disobey your father
In being rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, so, it takes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You and your second selfe shall home with me
Until his furious humour be blown over.
To which the first meanes is to shun his sight,
And then let me alone to make your peace.

sp.speaker: Joy. Gab.
sp.l: We thank your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: So let us slip.
Home to my house together.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hist brother, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As glad as ever Fox was of his prey
sp.stage: Exit. om. Pet. Mat. Er. Vab.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis even so, Gentlemen, sorrow findes no lodging.
In my light heart sometimes she knocks at door,
And takes a drink, but here she must not sit by't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y'are happy Sir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet I have heard you say
You never tasted joy for divers yeares
Till your wife died: since when, a King of mirth,
And now to marry agen is such a thing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes sir, tis such a thing that I will marry
That I fore know can never disobey me
And I'll defie the devil to dishonest her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Is she so ougly?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, he means so vertuous.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-said, sir, you shall drink before me. Rachel, Mawdlin.
sp.l: 'Protest you shall though't be in my own house.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now he resumes his humour.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ratchel I say,
Bring me a kan o' sack.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But how can you
Presume before the dangerous marriage-trial
That she whom y'have chosen will be obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: D' ye think he has not tried her? There's a question

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-said agen. I was about to say so.
Rachel, some sack, I say. Yes, I have tried her, sir,
Tri'd her, and tri'd her again; all over and over
These five yeares day and night; and still obedient.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Then you are sure to her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I never us'd
A marriage-question, not a woing word,
But do all by command, she is so obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And yet she's chaste and vertuous withal.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-said again, sir, so I was a saying.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But we have talk't away the Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No matter, let'hem go. Would they were far enough.
sp.stage: Enter Rachel, silver Kan and Napkin.
sp.p: Come, the sack, the sack.— Who taught you that courtesie maid.
sp.l: Pray try a better to the Gentleman.
Protest you shall begin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your own house, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll rather g' ye my house, then break my word in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Y'are Lord here, and may command me, sir. And so my service to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll do you reason, sir.
Be ready with your Napkin, and a lower douke maid.
I'll hang dead weight at your buttocks else. So.
Is not this obedience, Gentlemen, Mr. Erasmus?
Mus, I will call thee Mus, I love to be
Familiar, where I love; and Godamercy
For your friend here; you both shall see my daughter.
But my French Damosel and I are parted
I hope by this time. So here's to you Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: To me, to me, to me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ha boy, art there? dispatch
Your court'sie quickly, and go cal my daughter.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: She is gone forth, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Forth, ha? when? whither?
La ye, she thinks I'm angry, and the finger
Is in the eye already. Is not this
Feare and obedience, Gentlemen? who went with her.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: She went with my Lady Nestlecock, to bring Gabriella on her way they said.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would
They were all in France together.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She comes again, I doubt not. Dry your eyes.
And drink that sack, without a court'sie, drink it.
You do not know my meaning, Gentlemen.
Stay: now gi' me't agen.— Now go and dry
Your face within— without a court'sie? ha!
Now is not this obedience, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But this is not the rare obedient peece
That you will marry?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You do not hear me say so.
But I presume, as much obedience
In her I have made choice of.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Marrie a maid.
And we will be her Hench-boyes, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I'll have no such blades 'bout my wives hanches.
But come, to end this tedious Scene, in which
I ha' past the Purgatorie of my Passions
Of sorrow, anger, feare, and hope at last.
I am refin'd, sublim'd, exalted, fixt
In my true Sphere of mirth; where love's my object.
And bloodie thought of black revenge cast by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Could your faire breast harbour a bloody thought?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: For some few minutes, in which extasie
I meant t' ha' gone, as other Gallants do.
To fight in France, forsooth, and charg'd my man
To draw up his Accompts, call in my moneys,
Thought to have made my Will—.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I saw your Cashier
Go forth e'ne now with a strong lusty Porter
Loaden with money: I will not say my teeth
Water'd at it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But 'twas enough to make
A very true mans fingers itch.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot
Think he is run away; but yet I like not
His carrying forth, when I say, fetch in money.
But this is from my purpose. Love ye mirth?
Let's in, and drink, and talk. That gives it birth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I prithee now, I prithee, prithie now
Urge me no more in this case; for I cannot,
Nor I wo' not so I wo' not, I be jealous
of mine own wife, mine own deat flesh and blood?
That's such a thing! I pidee speak no more on't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You shew you love Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So I hope I do Nan.
My cock, my pity nittle nansie cocksie,
Do I not shew my love when I deny thee
Vnreasonable requests? I never heard
Of woman that desir'd a loving husband
To be a jealous Master over her.
Especially a City-Shopkeeper.
The best part of whose trade runs through the hands
Of his faire wife too! 'Tis unreasonable.
And thou the first that e're take up the humour.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you the first that e're I knew besotted
Into a wilful confidence, which renders
Me to a vile construction; and your selfe
By leaving me to all assaults and hazards
Have got the reputation of a Wittal.
Or one that seems contented to become so.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Hon soit qui maly ponse.
My Cock, my Nansie Cock, my Cocksie Nansie,
Kisse me, and use thine own conscience: I scorn
The yellow sicknesse, I, let 'hem all say what they will.
D'einty, come thou to me. I will not lose
An haires bredth o' my humour, nor retain
An ill thought o' my Cocks honestie
For all the wealth i' the Exchange, not I

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I not desire you should, but only that
You will not seem so carelesse of my credit,
Exposing me to all temptations
Of the wilde Gallantry of the wanton time.
By whom (although my chastity remaines
Untouch't) my name and your discretion suffers.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish, Honi soit again: Cock, I defie
Calumniation and detraction I.
When I am jealous, let the horne-curse take me;
And let me be with hornets stung to death.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Still you flie from the point, I would not have
You vex your self with causelesse jealousie
Over my constant love; but only seem
A little watchful o're my reputation.
Whereby you may decline mens leud attempts.
And not to throw me upon opportunities
To draw them on; as if I were a thing
Set out, as in your shop, for common sale.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, Thou shalt never tie me to't: not I.
I must not lose my harmlesse recreations
Abroad to snook over my wife at home.
Thought'st ha' me like the hair-brain'd Point-tagger,
That us'd to hammer his fingers at one end
O'th' shop, while's wife was bargaining at the other?
Not I; sweet Cock, pidee lets heare no more on't.
Now friend! Is your businesse to me or my wife?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: This Superscription will inform you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To my deare daughter Mrs. Hannah Camelion, at her shop or house in or near the New Exchange.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Take it quickly, what a Knave art thou to put a letter in my hands, that is directed to my wife. Sbobs I would not ha' open'd it for fourty pound.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: If all husbands in the City were of his minde, it were a Forrest of fooles indeed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I must leave thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Pray stay a little. This letter's from my father.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I hope the good Captaine's well.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, very well, pray read his Letter here.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, you shall pardon me. Not I.
I have a match to play at the ducking-pond.
Prithee fore-slow not my occasions, Cock,
As I forbear to pry into thy secrets.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Here's nothing but what I would have you see.
There's for your postage, friend. It needs no answer.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I thank you, Mystris.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But if you will not stay to reade this Letter.
You shall not deny me one thing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What is it, quickly? my sweet Nanny Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here, take this pen: write here a word or sentence.
What you please. But keep it well in minde,
And look that you be sure to know't agen
When I shall shew't you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis done, there: I defie, and dare the devil and all his Clerks to counterfeit my hand. So, my sweet Cock, a kisse and adieu.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well Rafe, remember that you won't be jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, Sbobs yonder comes one of the Blades,
That thou would'st have me have an eye to; He
That lives by his wits, and yet is seldom sober:
That goes so gallantly, and has no credit,
Nor ever buyes with ready money; But
Barters commodity for commodity.
(Such as it is) with Tradesmens wives, they say.
What call you him, oh Askal; there's another
Comes with him too. Into thy shop, good Cock.
I wo' not stay, not I. So, farewel Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And farewel Coxscombe, some wife would say now.
I am much troubled at his sillinesse.
And would to right me, straine a womans wit,
Knew I with modesty how to answer it.
Something I'le do.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Was ever such a humour in a man, as this mad
Merchant Matchil is possest with.
To marry so, to spight his childe and kindred.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has made his daughter by't a match worth nothing.
And there your hope is gone.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And yours in me.
For as I said before, good Valentine.
I must returne you to your City wives.
By the old trade to pick your maintenance
Out of em, as you boast you can.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well, sir.
And now to let you know that I can live
Without the helps of such cool friends as you.
I'le shew you a present probability.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doest see yond pretty mumping peece i'th' shop there?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, is that one—?

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: One o'th' fourty, boy,
That renders tribute in to my Exchecquer.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Didst ever lie with her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How plain you are. Not I, not I.
That's her fool-husbands word.
Let it sussice that I have seen her thrice.
And that I lay with, drink, and weare her money.
O 'tis the sweetest Rogue.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: How got you acquainted.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le tell you that, walking by chance as now,
Before her shop, where a young Gentleman
Was bargaining, he call'd me by my name,

sp.speaker: Val Askall.
sp.l: Instantly her eye was fixt,
And streight ran over my delineaments,
Which I set to her view; and took occasion
To ask her how the object pleas'd her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Bold-face.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I never lost by that.
She then demands, Is your name Askall, sir?
I answer, Yes. Pray of what countrey, sir?
I told her; when a sudden flaming blush
Did in her face betray the fire of love,
That was at th' instant raging in her breast,
She look't me through and through. Sigh'd, turn'd away.
Then look't again under her hat-brims thus.
And thus I nimbly catch't her with mine eye.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I, thou hast a devillish catch i'that same eye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, what I have, I have. I gave a leere
With that same eye that made her turne her whites up.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But to the point.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why do you think a woman's so quickly brought to th' point?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What follow'd then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I saw she was struck, and thus I gave her line
To play withal. I whisper'd in her eare,
The way to finde my lodging and my service.
Next morning early comes a message to me,
Inviting me to dinner: Chear and welcome
Plenteously flowed; and sir, before we parted
Upon some private conference, twenty pieces
Were clutch't into this hand, but with a caution
To be discreet and thrifty of her purse,
And keep a friend in store. I have been modest,
And have not struck her since, but for ten more.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And that's your last.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I le hold you ten uh that
See she has spied me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: What lack ye, Gentlemen; faire cut-work bands, boot-hoose, or boot-hoose tops, shirts, wast-coats, night-caps, what will you buy?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I come not now to buy.
But in plain termes to borrow. Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not on these termes.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sure thou mistak'st the woman.
This is not she, thou talk'st so freely on Bounce.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She's cautious before thee. Walk off a little.
Now you may hear me, Lady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Give me leave
A little, first to wonder at your rashnesse,
To talk so openly before a stranger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My intimate friend: I'le trust him with my life.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What's that to my unblemish't reputation?
'Tis not your life can salve that, being wounded.
But thus it is, when women out of goodnesse
Hazard their fortunes to relieve the wants
Of such as you, that carry no respect,
But to your own licentious Appetites.
And think no favour's sweet, unlesse you may
Have priviledge to boast 'hem to our shame.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do not boast of yours.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Pray, boast no more
Then you have found, and much good may they do you.
'Tis not poor thirty pieces can undo me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, nor ten more I hope; and that's the summe
I would entreat: all makes but fourty pound.
I'll pay thee like a Gentleman, as I am one,
Either in money; or doest hear me, Rogue,
In what shall please thee better. Come, be wise,
Thy husband's a dull ducking Gamester. And
Kennels his water-dog in Turnbull-street.
We'll answer his delights with better sport.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: There's your presumption.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, 'tis my ambition.
When shall we walk to Totnam? or crosse o're
The water, or take Coach to Kengington
Or Padington; or to some one or other
O'th' City out-leaps for an afternoon,
And hear the Cuckow sing to th' purpose? when?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.l: A woman were a wise one that would trust
Her selfe in such wilde hands as yours; to have
Her name made Tavern-talk among your blade,
And thrust i'th' list of your loose-hilted Mystresses:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O no; fie no: you cannot think how close
And careful I will be. Heark in thine eare.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cannot blame this fellow now so much
For using of his wits to get his living,
Though in an idle way; as for traducing
People of worth and vertue, as this woman
Who I am credibly inform'd is vertuous
And too discreet for him to shark upon.
Therefore to grace himself, he slanders her.
I have alwayes lik't his company till now,
And shall hereafter be more wary of him.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well sir, upon your faithful protestation,
And vow of secresie, here's ten pieces more.
You have found a tender-hearted woman of me
Over your wants; and all the satisfaction
That I desire, is, that I may not suffer
Under a lavish tongue; 'tis easie payment.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, but I'le pay thee better. Therefore tell me, when we shall meet and have a spirt abroad.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Your friend stayes for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pish, let him stay.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: You slight him now, but he knows all your Councels.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By this good tongue, no more then the unbegotten Hans that I mean to clap into thy Kelder.
sp.l: Nor ever shall: doest think I am so foolish
To talk away my hopes? No, thou art my Faery,
Pinch me to death when I discover thee.

sp.speaker: Han,
sp.l: Go to, avoid suspition then, besides
I have occasions that do call me hence.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Your stay was somewhat long.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet 'twas to purpose.
As here you may behold, but I must make no words on't.
She has enjoyn'd me that. O 'tis a cunning Gypsie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So't seems, by trusting thee that hast no power to keep a secret.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, to tell you true.
My conscience will not beare't, I cannot be
So ungrateful to receive a courtesie,
But to acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet thou hast the conscience
To work a mans estate out of his hands
By his wives frailty, even to break his back.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis rather to be fear'd she may break mine.
She's a tight strong dock't Tit.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O Tradesmen, why do you marry?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why? to make Tradeswomen.
For Gentlemen that want money and commodity.
You know the thing that I call father-in-law,
That had my mothers whole estate, and butied her,
Allowes me nothing.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thank your own sweet courses.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My courses are sweet courses, they serve me to live upon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But I shall put you off
O'one of your sweet courses, or at least
I'le strain a point of friendship to be satisfied
Touching this woman, 'twill be worth discovery.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But why these cloudy looks? do not you like my courses? ha!

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy, Val.
I was upon our former subject Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I there's a hasty match clap't up. You ask't
Why Tradesmen marry, there's a marriage now!
A humorous Coxscombe that could never laugh
In all his last wives dayes; and since her death
Could ne're be sad. For him to marry his Malkin
For poor and course obedience. Well. I hope
To take my course in his house yet for all.
Her boasted chastity and obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wouldest thou touch such a thing?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, not for money?
She can pay well and her uglinesse cannot fright me
I can do that work winking.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She can be no such woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tell not me
What any woman can or cannot be,
You'll give me leave to try my fortune with her,

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, and walk with you towards it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No newes, no tidings of 'em, Ephraim, ha!
Was even sucg a scape?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Not since the Rape
Of Hellen I'm perswaded. I have search't
With narrow eyes (as I may say) with care,
And diligence in most secret places.
And can no way inform my self, what is
Betide of the young Damosels, or old Squire.
Your Neece, and the French Virgin, and the man
Unworthy to be call'd your brother Strigood.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O hang him Villain.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Doubtlesse 'twas his plot
To work upon your Ladiships good nature
To harbour them, that he might take th' advantage
Of stealing them away.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What to do, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: To do? much may be done by his seducements,
On two such tender Virgins, though he should
But plant them in our suburbs: but my feare
Is that he has transported them beyond seas
Into some Nunnery. Your Ladiship
Knows he is adverse in Religion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know he is of none.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Satan will work.
The stronger in him, then to their subversion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How shall I answer now my brother Matchil?
But he is justly serv'd to marry so.
The thought of it torments me. Where's my comfort?
Where's Nehemiah, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: He's busie, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What, at his book? or at his musick, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: That is, his Ballet, or his Jewes Trump. No,
Madam. He is busie at his exercise of Armes
With a new Casting top, a Cat and Catstick,
I bought and brought him home.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you for 'hem,
My careful discreet Ephraim. I like
His harmlesse exercises well.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I hope,
Your Ladiship can say since I have had
The Government of him under your Ladiship,
I have been careful of the Gentleman,
And have his love withal so much, that I
Dare say (I hope you'll pardon the comparison)
That had you married me (which was as likely
As that your brother would have ta'ne his Maid.
I think that Mr. Nehemiah would not
Have run away in hatred of our Match,
As Mrs. Joyce. it seems, hath done of theirs.
I hope your Ladiships pardon, I understand
My duty.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And you speak but reason Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I have given her there a touch of my affection.
Who knowes how it may work?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go call him in.
I would not have him over heat himself.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: 'Tis a good care. And Madam, by the way,
Let me advise, that since his riper yeares
Require, and that faire Propositions
Of marriage are tender'd for him, that
We gently by degrees, do take him off
From childish exercise, indeed plaine boyes play.
More manly would become him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You would have him
Do worse then, would you? and be nought, you varlet?
What! would you have him play at Mans-game, ha?
Fore he be married, ha! what, what! how now!
Is it but up and ride w'ye, ha!

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I humbly
Beseech your Ladiships pardon, I will call
Sweet Mr. Nehemiah to your worship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go, th'art an honest man. I know thou lov'st him.
Indeed he's all my comfort and my care
And I must naturally respect all those
That do partake with me my care of him.
sp.stage: Enter Nehemiah, looking down and eating.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: my boy Negh, Sonne Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: F'sooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That's my good Lamb. Hold up thy head; and thou.
Shalt have a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But mother f sooth, when I have her,
Will she play with me at peg-top?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: At any thing, my boy.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And she ha' not good box and steel, I shall so grull her.
And then at Mumbledepeg I will so firk her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But when y'are married, you'll finde other pastime.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Whate're I say, I have a meaning though.
But yet, I doubt, I shall not forsake all
My old fagaries in a yeare or two.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know thy will is good to leave thy wag-tricks.
And I commend your understanding in it.
It shewes you man, and ready for a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, f'sooth, I think so; I Amardla.
For I did beat a boy as high as my selfe
Yesterday, with one hand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where was thy tother.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: The boy had but one hand f'sooth. I us'd both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well th'art too witty to live long, I feare.
But as I was saying, sonne, I do expect
Sir Swithen Whimtby to bring his Neece.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Who f'sooth, the crying Knight, he that has wept
E're since his Lady di'd; and mournes in colours;
Speaks nothing but in verse, and gives me Ballats;
The old Knight Powel, that pronounces what dee call 'hem?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Odes childe and Elegies. He has been inspir'd.
With the infection of Poetry,
E're since his wives departure: and 'tis thought
Nothing can put him out, or cure him of it
But a new wife to kill the furious itch of't,

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But is not his Neece too big for me? I would be loth
To be over-match'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O witty, witry, still.
But when she comes Nehemiah, what'll you say to her?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: I'll give her the time of the day or the night
I warrant her, come at what houre she will.
Why if I eat not all before she come.
(And she must try her, if I do'nt) I'll ask her
If she can speak with plums in her mouth; and then
I'll offer her a long one and two round ones,
And nod at her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You will not, will you, ha?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, I know both what to say and do
I trust I am not to be taught to wooe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Too witty still, I say, to be long-liv'd.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But heark you mother f'sooth; I am told that you
Beare a moneths minde to that Sir Whimlby,
And a crosse match is talk't on betwixt you
And the old Knight, and me and his young Neece.
O ho— is't so?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is no crafty childe.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Let me but see how you will handle him now
And mark how I'le come over her with small Jerks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O th'art a witty wag. A blessing on it.
sp.stage: Enter Ephraim, ushering Whimlby and Blith.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, Sir Swithen Whimlby and his Neece,
Mrs. Blith Tripshort.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They are very welcome,
Noble Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Noble Mrs. Blith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sweet Knight, y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Welcome, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Still weeping.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: O good Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Still weeping for a husband.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, she puts me on't,
She laughes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Laugh with her then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, so I will, and if you laugh
At me, I'll laugh at you again, so I will.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Are you there with me? I'le be here with you then.
Will you eat any Sugar-plums? no, I'le eat 'em for you.
There's ha, ha, ha, ha, for you now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do you note, Sir Swithin, what a wag it is.
Walk into the next room Nehemiah. Did you note him?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Madam, to tell you true.
My love to you
Springs from the joy,
I take in your sweet boy
sp.stage: — Eph. And that's the way to win her.
sp.l: I can take no delight
But in his sight,
Nor any pride
Since my dear Grissel di'd,
In all, I see on earth or finde in books,
But that which overcomes me in his lookes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O sweet Sir Swithen, you have all woo'd and won me.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Then all my hopes are frustrate.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My sonne shall have your Neece, and for mine own part.
You loving him so well, of what's in me.
I can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Gentle Madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: She offers up her selfe; now may the proverb
Of proffer'd service light upon her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay, Sir Swithen.
Let me entreat you to leave weeping now.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Madam, I cannot so
Forego my woe.
For while I strive
My solace to revive,
I do but still restore
My grief, before
That did beti'd
When my dear Grissel did.
And when your Ladiship appears in sight.
(Pardon) I cannot chuse but cry out-right.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, good Knight. He weeps pure Helicon.
He has not wherewithal to quench his love,
But his own teares. A wife would cool him better.
Why sir, does sight of me renew your grief?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: O Madam, Madam, yes;
In you the blisse,
That I do misse,
I finde inshrined is.
And till, to ease my paine,
I shall regain
In you the Bride,
That in my Grissel di'd.
So oft as she in you to me appears
My numbers cannot cease to flow in tears.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good sir, collect your self, and be assur'd
I am your own, so Neh. may have your Neece,
With her full Dowry of foure thousand pounds.
My personal estate is full as much.
That and my self are yours on the crosse marriage,
You making me an answerable Joincture.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Is't come so near; I'le crosse it, or my star
Drop crosses on my head. O vain, vain woman,
To doat on Poetry in an old man.
Ladies may love it in the young and bold,
And when they are sick give gally-pots of gold,
For cordial Electuaries to chear
Their crop-sick Muses; but to an old and sere
Man that out-lives his labours, who can be
So vain to give her self away but she.
I had been sitter for her, and I'le watch
Occasion yet, perhaps, to crosse the match,
I can turn Poet too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dry now your eyes, and answer me in prose,
Are you content to yield to those conditions
I have propounded, ha!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I am content.
And now for joy could weep,
Finding my Grissel in your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I hope the young ones do accord as well.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Protest, I cannot abide you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Nor I you.
Amardla, that I cannot.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: They'r agreed.
Madam, it seems they both are of one minde.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: I do not like it. What's the matter Nehemiah?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: She is no wife for me, she has broke my Jewes-trump; look you here else. And almost broke my head with one of my bounding stones.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Blesse my boy; she has not, has she, ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And yet after all that, and for all I offered to teach her to shoot in my Trunk and my Stone-bowe, do you think she would play with me at Trou, Madam? no, nor at any thing else. I'll none of her.
And yet I'le have her too. If she will promise to do as I would have her hereafter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There, do you note him there, Sir Swithen?
This childe has no childish meaning in't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: No Madam, no, I know him inwardly
He is my joy, and she shall be conformable,
Or fare the worse.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: She will, I know she will.
Will you not have my son, sweet Mrs. Blith?

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Sweet Madam, what to do? ha, ha, I shall be quickly weary with laughing at him. His fooling will soon be stale and tedious; and then to beat him would be as toilsome to me; and lastly, to be tied to nothing but to cuckold him, is such a common Town-trick, that I scorne to follow the fashion.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: Can she talk thus? ha!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A merry harmlesse Girle.
Fear not, good Madam, she will come about.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: A thousand mile about rather then meet him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I much desire she would; for now my sonne
Is set a marrying, I warrant it pure thing
It is in paine, till it be at it: ha!
Pray bring her on, Sir Swithen, let him kisse her.
Poor heart, he licks his lips; and look how arseward she is.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Fie Blith, be courteous, Blith.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother,— she has spit Amard just in my mouth.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Amard, what's that? if you speak French you wrong me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Gip, Mrs. Tripshort. Is this the manners your Mother left you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Speak not you of Mothers, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir Swithen, will you see my childe abus'd so, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I can but grieve for't, Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: My mother is as good as your mother, so she is, for all she's dead.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I, well-said Neh.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Yes, it appears in your good breeding
Your fine qualities expresse her vertues sussiciently.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How dare you Huswife talk thus to my son, of me, and before my face too? ha! Sir Swithen, can you think well of me, and suffer this, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Alas, good Madam, I am down again I know not what to think of living woman now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you bring your Neece to abuse me?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I am so drown'd in teares, that I cannot see what to say to't.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, Amardla, the more I look on her, the better I like her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sayest so, my boy. Besides, I have a conceit she can out-scold you, and that's more then ever woman did, I think f'sooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For thee, I do forbear her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: By your leave, my Lady Nestlecock, I have brought a sister of yours here to salute you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Though unworthy to be of your Counsel, or at the Ceremony, I heard you were married brother. And by a Sisters name you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I thank your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir Swithen Whimlby! and your pretty Neece! well met, what affairs have you in hand here? what do you cry for your old wife still or for a new one? But heark, you Lady Sister, where's my daughter?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now for a tempest. Truly sir, I know not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is she not with you, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No truly, sir.
She's slipt from me with her good Uncle Strigood.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That Thief has sold her then into some Bawdihouse
Was this your project for her education,
To steal my childe to make a whore of her?
Are you turn'd Lady-baud now for your Neece
Because you have no daughter? O the devil!
If there be Law, I'll trounce your Lady Hagship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what? how now? do you taunt me, sirrah, ha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll make thee an example.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou hast made thy self an example, and the scorne of thine own childe in marrying of thy drudge there; and that's the cause of her running away thou mayest think, because she hates to live where she must call her mother that was thy droile.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Droile, I think, she said.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Speak to her, I charge thee, on thy obedience to speak to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The droile is now your brothers wife, Madam, and in that setting your Ladiships lavish tongue aside, as good a woman as your selfe, none disprais'd, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-said Rachel, hold thine own Rachel. And so to you, sir Sw then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, come away, mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By and by, my boy.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Do you presume to call me drudge and droile, that am a Ladies Sister every day in the week; and have been any time these three dayes, ha.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: That's not every day in a whole week yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou shalt not dare to call me sister Huswife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Cods so, and why troe? because a Lady scornes to be a huswife, ha. If you be no huswife, I scorn to call
you Sister, I; though my husband be your brother. From whence came you troe, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to say to the bold-face.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'sooth come away, I am afear'd she'l beat you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thanks, my good childe, but do not be afraid my Lamb.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Boldface, ha! Her brothers wife▪ s a bold-face, but her face is not varnish't over, yet like his Ladysisters face, but it may be in time when she learnes the trick on't, and have as many flies upon't, though not so troubled with 'hem, as a bald mare at Midsummer, hah.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to say to her, she has charm'd the vertue of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I never heard her speak so much in all her life, Sir Swithin, nor half so loud. hank heaven, she has a voice yet on a good occasion. And so farre I'll maintain her in it. Nephew Nehemiah, when saw you your Cousin Joyce.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O Lud, O mother f'sooth, look you, mine Uncle holds me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ah, naughty man, did a so gi'' me a stroke, and I'll beat it, ah—.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Your wife has taught you to play the rude companion, has she? Pray take her home sir, and let her discipline your owne childe if you have one, and let mine alone. You know the way you came, sir; or if you have a minde to stay here, Come Sir Swithen, come away children; I hope I shall finde some other room in mine own house, free from your assaults, if not, I'm sure there's Law against Riots. Come Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Not yet good Madam Nestlecock, you shall hear me.
You have entic'd away, then lost my daughter.
And now y'are a jugling with your widow wit,
And your small worme here, to catch up for Gudgeons.
Sir Swithen and his Neece, I know your plot..
She's not fit match for you Sir Swithen; and her son
Much lesse for your faire Neece. Come dry your eyes,
And look upon him, and not only look,
But laugh at him, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: I could now for him heartily.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Mark how his mothers milk drops at his nose, while I shew you the mother and the childe.
He was her youngest sonne, and all that's left of seven, and dreaming that he needs must prove a Prophet, she has bred him up a fool.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: F'sooth mother he mocks me, oh.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O prophane wretch, worse then thy brother Strigood.
sp.l: Do not cry, Nehemiah, peace, good boy, peace. So so.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A tender mother I must say she has been.
For till he was fifteen, none but her selfe
Must look his head, or wash his pretty face
For making of it cry. Laugh at her good Sir Swithen.
And before that, till he was twelve yeares old
She would dance him on her knee, and play with's Cock.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Ah ah ah ah.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So well-said, Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Just so efac my mother would serve me, ha, ha.
Is not this better then whining.
Yes, or perhaps then wiving either.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.l: Do you say so.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Well said, Sir Swithen, laugh on. I hope I ha' done a cure on him, by shewing him a
more ridiculous object then himselfe, to turne the tide of's tears.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Laugh still, defie the fiends, women, and all their works.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, let the dead go, and the quick care for themselves. You buri'd your wife, and cri'd, and I buried mine.
sp.l: And laugh; which is the manlier Passion.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He knows not that he is married agen.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: You are the merriest Merchant, ha, ha, ha.
I think I shall not marry again in haste, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-said, hold there. And for your Neece
Let me alone. I'le fit her with a match.
I know a Lad that's worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He'll laugh too much, I feare.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He may at you,
For your officiousnesse.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: To thrust your self into unthankful offices.
In things concerne you not. Will you turne Matchmaker
For others un-intreated, 'tis enough.
For you, I hope, that you have match't your selfe, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hah! Do you hab, or talk to me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Who else
Should talk or give you counsel but your wife?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well-said Rachel, hold thine own Rachel.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am match't again.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pax, cry again, or burst thy self with laughing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: La. Ha, ha, ha. Laugh son Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Ha, ha. ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What am I? what do you make of me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, what ha' you made your self? best ask the Chimney piece that you have married there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Durst thou advance a voice against me, ha?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You did commend it in me against your Sister.
And I may better be familiar with you;
Hah, are you not my husband? I am sure
'Tis not so long since we were married, that
You can forget it, or repent so soon.
I am not now your slave, to have my face
Wash't with your snuffes, nor to be kick't and trod on
Without resistance, nor to make you answers
Meerly with silent court'sies, run when you bid go
To fetch and carry like your Spaniel,
In which condition I liv'd long enough,
And was content until you freed me out on't.
Now free I am, and will be a free woman,
As you are a free-man, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O base-borne begger.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You wrong your wife in that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How she holds up the wife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I never beg'd
Nor mov'd a lip to be your wife, not I,
You held my service portion good enough,
And for my blood 'tis no more base then yours,
Since both are mixt in marriage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Come your way.
And let me hear you speak so much at home.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I hope I may be bolder in mine own house.
So Madam, for the love I have found in yours,
You shall be welcome thither, when y'are sent for.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What a bold piece of Kitchin-stuffe is this?
Brother y'are match't.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: And catch't ifacla, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He has not a word to speak.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Follow me home and durst.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes sir, I dare without more leave taking, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Was ever combe so cut.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: There's a new Aunt indeed! she brought me nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: I have not laught so much I know not when,
H'has made me laugh until I cry agen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Again, you are welcom, Sir, Mrs. Blith
Now the unwelcome guests are gone, lets in
And dine, then will we after meat

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Of Joinctures, Madam, and of Nuptials treat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Right sir.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Love, as I shall adore thee for a deity.
Rid me of this ridiculous society.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Matchil, Rachel, between Erasmus and Valentine.

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.p: GOod Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Mystris, be not so violent.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll rather run my Countrey, Gentlemen, then endure her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You were best to kill her then, and then you'll have no other course to take, unlesse you stay and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'le make thee glad to flie first.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: From my house and husband shall I? from my possessions shall I? And leave you all to spend in riot shall I? No sir, I'le stay and spend my share if you go to that, that will I. And make all flie as well as you, and you go to that, that will I, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Whoop, whow.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Nay, Ile be not so loud.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What didst thou bring thou drudge thou.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That which you were content to drudge withal, I am too sure o' that. The drudge you speak of is no worse then your own wife, I am too sure o'that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I know not what to say to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Did you not say for better, for worse? And if 'twere worse then 'tis, 'twere all too good for you. And that I hope I shall finde some good Friend to know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That I like well, I'le be her first man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I trust you have found the drudge to be a woman fit to content a man, and if you grant not that, some better man perhaps shall be a Judge, betwixt you and the drudge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Better still.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She threatens hornes. I think.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hornes. I think, you said. If 'twere so 'twere too good for you. Cannot your own wife content you, ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She holds up that point stoutly.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That shall be tri'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O for an expert Chyrurgion now to cast her in a dead sleep, and geld her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Introth you will be both sorry, when your passion gives but least way to your understandings. Mr. Matchil, let me perswade with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Never uniesse you bring her on her knees, to crave forgivenesse at my foot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you but yield an inch he treads upon your neck, I will not give an under spur-leather for you. But bear it out bravely, and I'll be your servant.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Mrs. Match-ill indeed, to be so match't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So match't▪ how match't? what from the hurden sinock with lockram upper-bodies, and hempen sheets, to weare and sleep in Holland, and from the dripping-pan to eat in silver, ha. Do you repine at your Match, ha. Is wealth contemptible to you?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I was better content in my povertie. I have not been my selfe, Gentlemen, since he married me.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: You may be poor again as soon as you please, the door is open, depart at your pleasure; you know the way to your old Aunt the Apple-woman, at Hockly-hole. Take your knitting Needles again, and live with her, go.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No sir, I'll stay with you, and make you as poor before I have done wi' ye, as I was before you had me Gent. I shall not be my self till then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The devil you shall. Was ever such a crooked condition crept into a thing like woman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet this sir, is the rare piece of obedience
You boasted of, and said you would defie
The devil to dishonest her, I am sorry
Your judgement led you into such an errour,
Already she's my Mystresse.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is she so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, and I'le call him servant, Gentlewomen use it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do so, Mystresse.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If she, sir, be your Mystresse, Then am I
Your Master-in-law, out of my house I charge you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Doest thou conspire to grieve him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, sir, I did but jest. You have my pity.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: All are not times for Jest, friend Valentine.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.p: O my affliction!

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Have a little patience, sir.
sp.l: While I talk calmly with her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Leave me then
A while unto my thoughts. Go into the house.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray servant help me here a little. Do so much
As winde up my Jack for me, my Watch I would say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her Jack▪ she's in the Kitchin still.
A pretty Watch this, Mystresse, what did you pay for't.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nothing, my husband ga't me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pity the Spring is broke, but I can get it mended.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Good servant take it with you then to the Jack-makers, I would say, the Watch-makers. Come Gentlemen, shall we have a crash at cards?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: With all my heart. What is your game?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can play a many old games. One and thirty bone-ace, Tickle me quicklie, and my Ladies hole, and sichie. But you shall teach me new ones, though I lose money for my learning, Gleek and Primero, Gresco saut, primofistula, I know all by hear-say. Come let us have a bout at somewhat. I have money enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I'le make shift to ease you of some on't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Affliction on affliction hourely findes me,
And layes me on the Rack, tearing my heart
Like greedie vultures, O my heart, this heart
That I so long suppos'd impenetrable
By all the darts of sorrow, is now transfixt,
Shot through and through with torments, and by this.
This last made sensible of all the rest.
My sons untimely death, my daughters losse.
My Sisters follies, and my Brothers vices.
My servants falshood, and the jeers of strangers
Now wound me all at once; and all through this
Predominant blow, pull'd on me by mine own
Impetuous rashnesse. Let me here consider,
While my hearts torture keeps my soule awake,
The moving cause of all these ill effects.
Mine own unbridled wilde affections.
Scorne of example, and contempt of counsel.
I cannot but observe withal, how just,
A judgement follows mine own wilful acts,
In the same kinde of doing ills for ills.
For my lost sonne, I rashly wrought revenge
Upon an innocent Girle; and with her
Have lost mine own; and for th'unmanly joy
I took in one wives death, because a Shrew.
(Though otherwise vertuous) I am in another
Trebly tormented; not alone with noise,
But with a feare of unchaste purposes,
Which if they come to act, my purse must pay for.
I see my faults, and feel the punishments.
And rather then stand out in my defence
T'enjoy some peace, I will endure some sorrow
And beare it civilly. Within there.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Go call your Mystresse, pray her to come alone.
My resolution brings me yet some ease:
Men that are borne to serve, must seek to please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.l: Your pleasure quickly, I have left
My company, my servant, and my friend yond,
Sawing against one another at Corne the Caster; till I come to 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And then all three to In and In, is't so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My servant, and my friend and I are e'ne all one.
They are the goodest Gentlemen, the best company.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your servant and your friend.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes, and my servant playes for me now in my absence, as farre as ten pieces go that I left him. My plow goes there, though I am here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your plow makes vile baulkes of my money the while.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am not so ill a huswife as you imagine. And my friend, and my servant have promis'd to carry me abroad, to this town, and to that town, and tother town, and whow, I know not whither. And my servant will have me to Hide-Park he sayes, to see and to shew all, as well as the brave Gallants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is gallant indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And my friend will carry me to a whatdeecall, a new Academy, where I shall see the rarest musick and dancing, he sayes, and learn the finest Complements. and other courtly qualities that are to be had for money, and such instructions for the newest fashions

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She will flie to the devil for fashions sake. Pray stay a little, and let me talk calmely with you. You have almost broke my heart.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But not altogether, I hope. I would not win so great a game, without some sport in playing it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear me.
I know you put on this affected carriage,
But to try masterie, and the disease
Being so general among all women,
Is in you therefore more excusable.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O, are you coming?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear what I will say to you.
And finde in that a husbands good affection.
I love my peace, and would preserve my honour,
Both which are in your breasts to save or spoil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And can you think the way to purchase peace
Is by a war with me? hah, you are cozen'd.
Do you think your domineering looks, or noise,
Or blowes, can fright me into quietnesse,
Or that you shall have honour by abasing
Your wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You will not understand me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Hah.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Though I love peace, and would preserve my honour.
I'le yield in both to you, and can, (I have been
So us'd to thraldome) But the world, the world
Is such a Talker.—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I have found the man.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There I would save a reputation.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He's loth to bring it out; I'le close w'ye.
You'll be content so, I will suffer you
To bear a loud command o're me in publick,
That I shall carrie it in private. Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Truly wife, yes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You'll give me leave to beat you
In private then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, we'll bar blowes at all times.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But if I chance to give you a rap or two,
Or now and then a nip, and you strike me
Again, I'le strike you some way else, as you
Would not be struck. And so observe my carriage.
The Gentlemen are coming.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O, here they are.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And not by the eares: that's wonderful.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Sir, I perceive my errour, and repent it.
Promising you in all my after life,
To be a faithful and obedient wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has fetch't her about, it seems.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Grammercy Rachel, binde it with a kisse.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And thus it should be.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, have ye found us?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: With joy to see this reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thus shall ye see it ever, Gentlemen.
I knew she would yield, or I should make her heart ake.
What were a husband, if he were not Master?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have wonne the field, it seems, yet I may hope
I have not lost a Mystresse.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor I a friend.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In a faire way, Gentlemen, I shall
Abridge her of no courtly priviledge.
But no more haytie twaytie tricks, I charge you.
She shall not jaunt to this nor that town with you.
(I thank you for your care) nor to Hide-Park.
Nor to the Academy you tell her of, without my leave.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And do you say so Mystresse?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Truly yes.
I am no such woman as you took me for,
With Mr. Matchils leave you may be welcome
Home to his house in good and seemly sort.
Put pray expect no further entertainment
Then he shall well allow of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have lost her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: This change is admirable.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Why do you admire it.
Is she not mine? how could you think she durst
Stand out in her rebellion? although the devil
Who soothes all Upstarts dispositions
Into an over-weening of themselves.
Possest her for a time, had not I power
And vertue do you think to conjure him out?
What have I studied for, think you, e're since
My last wife di'd, but how to rule the next?
Go get you in, there's something in the house
Worth looking after.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I be sworn, he frights her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Would I had you within to perform covenants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What do you grow rebellious again.
Why stir you not else, ha? prithee Sweetheart
Respect my dignity, or only seem to do it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, I will only seem to do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He makes her tremble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I must about my house-affaires.
So, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Good Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Aha.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And Mr. Matchil, at your own good pleasure.
Having in private something to impart to you,
I would entreat your presence.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Your eare before I go good Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: H'has brought her to her servile old obedience.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O—oh.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: That is a private touch, sir, of the businesse.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pox of your Lobster claws. There waanip!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: It will be worth consideration, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, Ile come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Any ill newes that you change colour so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, nothing, nothing but a womanish feare.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, you are a happy man that have o' her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You know not me yet Gentlemen, I know a word in private would do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet she desires to have you again in private.

sp.speaker: Mat.
