sp.l: 'Tis her abundant love, and pure obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She comes again.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Since y'are not yet dispos'd to enter, sir.
One word more, Mr. Matchil, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh,— I understand you. Go, I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Again, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I must weare Lantern-hornes upon mine arms,
If she use this. Well, Gentlemen, at your own time
Lets see yee. My Rach. shall make you welcome,
And for me, you know me, I will still be Master.—
I come, I come, I come. So, farewel Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha, do you run?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What doest thou think of this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le lay all the tricks I have against his brags.
She masters him in private, and that all
This shew of her obedience is dissembled.
My hope revives again; we must abroad with her.
But tell me, what new Academy's that
You told her of, I understand not that yet.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor have I seen it, but we both will shortlie.
'Tis but of two or three dayes standing yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where is it? who are the Professours,
And what the Arts?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I'le tell thee all know.
It carries a love-sound; but I am told
It is but private lodgings kept by
Both men and women, as I am inform'd, after the French manner.
That professe Musick, Dancing, Fashion, Complement.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And no drabbing?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: A little perhaps in private.
But guesse now in whose house all this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Even in your City-Mystresses, that lends you
Money so freely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who Camelion?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes sir, I doubt, your borrowing of the wife
Has broke the husband, put'hem off their trade,
And now they seek new wayes to live by projects.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And could you keep this from me all this while,
Till I am there, each step's a tedious mile.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But not without me, good Val. We'll finde a time.
Together, and our Mrs. Matchil with us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I protest Cock, I commend thy course
Thou hast taken in brave Lodgers, gallant Guests,
Guests o'th' Game Cock; and my house is counted
A house of quality and recreation, Cock,
In civil sort and gentle fashion, Cock,
Sbobs Cock, I know thou wouldest not have it otherwise
For all the wealth i'th' Exchange.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But Rafe you care not
What people say, so I bring you in profit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, not I, my little Cocksie Nansie,
Not I, pish, Hony soit qui maly pense.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Some do not stick to say, I know what's what,
And that our house is no better then it should be.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish, Hony soit agen, i'th' very teeth of 'hem,
Let 'hem all say what they will. Dainty come thou to me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But I know what I know, and that our house is
Better then it should be, if some of them
Had but the keeping of it, that speak so ill on't.
And that the Gentlewomen in our house
Are well-condition'd, and as chaste as courteous.
And if you saw, (as they desire I should
See all betwixt their great Resorts and them)
You'd be in love with their sweet way of living.
Then for their dancing, 'tis so neat and graceful.
See 'hem anon at practice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, Cock, I'le see nothing.
I will not leave one ducking pond, for ten dancing schooles.
Yet I can dance, and love it: you know that Cock.
And though you are a Gentlewoman borne,
You took me for my legs, not for my armes.
Is not that a good Jest, Cock. Sbobs 'twas out before
I was aware. Here comes their father.
sp.stage: Enter Strigood, Cash, disguiz'd in bravery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It seems he has brought in some new scholar.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Where are my daughters, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Close in their chamber, sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Are none of our Academicks come yet?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not any, sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I look for some anon
Pray bid the Girles come down
To practise.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Sir, when I was a Batchelour, I practis'd,
Dauncing sometimes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Indeed, good Landlord?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And maugre wedlock, I have something left
Yet in these legs, that can expresse at least
Love to the quality.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: That shall not be lost,
If I can further it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I saw last night
Your new French daunce of three, what call you it?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I think I could make one in't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: This Gentleman's another, call the Musick.
I'le try what you can do.
Cash, Thou art welcom, I am glad I met thee.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: But that you had foreknowledge of my habit,
And seen it in my out-leaps, as you call 'hem,
I might ha' past. But you in this disguise,
None but the devil himself that is your Inmate,
And lodges with you in it, could have known you.
Sure he devis'd it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: No, you are short.
I learn't it of a Jesuite.
And 'twas but easie: shaving of my old
Gray haire and beard off; clapping on this perrule
After the fashion; having but few wrinkles.
(For which I thank my Batchelourship, I passe
For a brisk youth. But for my Hannibal eye here. And by my brothers
Courteous advice I have ta'ne a course to live
Vpon my stock of wit, slight and activity,
With nimble braine, quick hands, and aery heels, as he told me, ha!

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: He could not think you would have stolne his daughter to ha' set up withal.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: But now I care not
What the wretch thinks, so he discovers nothing,
I dare trust thee Cash, partly on thy Oath
Which I have ta'ne you know: but more respectively
Upon your fourty pieces here, friend Cash,
Which I have also ta'ne: but most of all
For that I know you dare not make discovery,
For feare of Little-ease. That were a prison
Too fearful for such bravery to stoop into.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: That keeps me still in awe. 'Tis well you know it.
But it is better, he has no suspition
That I am run away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Musick's ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Play then,— the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Twas very well done, Landlord, I protest
I love your house the better for your quality.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But if you saw me at the ducking pond,
Me and my Trull.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Your Trull?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I mean, my bitch, sir.
O she would ravish you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Some other time.
Here comes your wife. The newes good Landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Newes out of France, your fame is spread abroad.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: How out of France?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Two young French Gentlemen.
New come ashore, the daintiest sweetest Gentlemen
That e're I saw (now you'll be jealous Rafe)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Are come to lodge here, having heard
It seems, that you professe French qualities.
And instantly desire to be acquainted
With you and your sweet company.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can they speak English?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: One very well: and the tother can say
Tree Fransh crown for two English kisse already,
Now be jealous Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish, Hony soit qui maly pense.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You can speak French, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So much as you have heard, not one word more.
I assure you but this, Adieu Monsieur and so
I leave you.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will you not see the Gallants Rafe?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, I wo'nt be jealous Cock, and so!
By the Back-door to the ducking pond. I go.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enter then Landlady, where be these Girles?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here they are come.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stand aside Cash, and be not yet discovered.
Now Ladies, how do y'like your way of living?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I do not like it Uncle.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Troth, nor I sir.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: We eat and lodge well; and we weare good cloathes.
And keep our credit in the house we live in,
But what we suffer in our reputation
Abroad, is dangerously doubtful.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Here we are view'd and review'd by all comers.
Courted and tempted too, and though w'are safe
In our chaste thoughts, the impious world may say,
We are set out to common sale.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And so you are to th' utmost of his power
I dare be sworne;

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But Uncle, for the time that you intend
To stay, I pray admit no new acquaintance,
Nor any more, lest I for my escape
Venture a leap two stories deep.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha! you said?
You know I have disclos'd you to no eye
That could take knowledge who or whence you are,
And for the forrein strangers, and such Townsfolks
As knew us not; what need we weigh their thoughts.
Their gold is weight; let that be all we look to.
While our deserving arts and qualities
Require it from 'hem. If they think us wicked,
And hope to get Virginities for salary,
And pay for their deluded hopes before-hand.
What is our act bnt Justice on their follies,
In taking of their prodigal coine?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I hope,
You deal not that way for us.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Never fear it.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But Uncle, though you have taught us courtly
Gypsie tricks.
That somewhat trench upon our modesties.
Pray let it not be thought we'll sell our honesties.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Trust to my care.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And that's the way to do it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And in that care be confidently seen,
By a deserving Gentleman, whom I
Present to kisse your hands.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I will see none.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You need not feare me, Lady; for I can
But tell your father, if you slight his servant.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Blesse us! what Metamorphosis is this?
'Tis Cash your fathers man.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Is this the habit of a Merchants Prentice?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Is this the lodging of a Merchants daughter?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Has his great marriage turn'd my fathers house
Into a sumptuous Palace, that he keeps
Such costly men. Or doth the bravery
Of his late beauteous Bride require such gorgeous
Attendants? Pray what office may you fill
About her person.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Will you home and see?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: We are betray'd?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Be not afraid of Cash.
I know him, and he knows us. He is our friend
And we'll be his. As for his bravery
'Tis no new thing with him. I know him of old.
This sute's his worst of foure.
And he's one
Of the foure famous Prentices o'th' time.
None of the Cream and Cake-boyes, nor of those,
That gall their hands with stool-balls, or their Catsticks,
For white-pots, pudding-pies, stew'd prunes, and Tansies.
To feast their Titts at Islington or Hogsden.
But haunts the famous Ordinaries o'th' time,
Where the best chear, best game, best company are frequent.
Lords call him Cousin at the Bowling Green; And the great Tennis-Court.
Thy fathers money
Would rust else, Girle. Keep thou our Councel Cash.
And we'll keep thine, though't be to the undoing
Of him and all the wretches of his brotherhood,
That love their money, and their base desires,
Better then blood or name.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: But can you hold
It good in any servant so to hazard
His Masters livelihood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can you hold your peace?
He's wise, and saves by't all this while: He knows
His friends are bound in full two thousand pounds,
For's truth, and his true service, and perhaps,
He is not out above one thousand yet,
Where's your wit now?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Mystresse, I'le do you service, and be true to you.
I'd not have mist of this discovery.—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You see she hearkens to him. Talk aside Cash.
And touch her boldly.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I would not have mist it.
For all the wealth your father has: and at
Convenient privacy. Ile give you reasons,
That shall gaine your belief to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: The French Gallants.
I had almost forgot them. They are a paire
Of delicate young Monsieurs. If they have
But crownes enough, they are the likelicst
Merchants for my new Mart that I can choose.
She said they can speak English, that's a help.
For devil of French have I to entertain 'hem.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: See mine own heart, here's more temptation still.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I'le not endure the onset.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I le defend you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Yet there are graces in their looks methinks,
That do invite my stay.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: N' entendes vous, la langue francois Monsieur dittez.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I would be glad to heare you speak the language
I better understand, and that is English.
In which you are most welcome.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Your faire courtesie
Merits our greatest thanks.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: I tanck you, sir.
I have bid Fraunce adieu to come and learn
De English very well; I speak a lietel,
But de English Mesteresse can teach de best.
I shall be glad to take my commencements,
Or my first Lessons from these Ladies lips.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: A fine forward spark?

sp.speaker: Gali
sp.l: O sweet, O delicate.
Ladies, if you will breath into me English,
I shall, if you please, put Fransh into you.
Une pour l'antre, dat is one for anoder.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: So they might make a hot bargain on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Are these your Civil Gentlemen, Landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: He seems a little waggish: but the other
Is wondrous civil. He comes blushingly.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: You are before me in the Salutation
Of these faire Ladies, Monsieur Galiard:

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Il E'vray Monsieur Papilion, I kisse before, then you mose kisse behind.
But let me pray my tardinesse be excus'd

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You pronounce English well sir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I am glad
You like it Lady.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I like the others as well.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I have before spent many monethes in England:
And my great love unto the Nation,
Especially to the beauties of your Sexe,
Retracts me hither, where my friend was never.
Till now that my perswasion wonne his company;
And happily, I suppose, we are arriv'd:
That, to the sight and knowledge we have had
Of Musick, Daunces, Courtships, and Behaviour.
Through all parts of our Countrey, France, with an
Addition of all Italy affords.
Where (by all best opinions) even the choicest
Of such court qualities, and active graces,
Have had their Spring, we now, as Fame suggests,
Shall in this faire Society, discerne
More then by all our former observation.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Report, sir, speaks too loud on our behalfe,
And let me pray ye, that it not beget
Too great an expectation on our weaknesse,
By your too gentle suffrage. What we can,
We'll do.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: O wee dats de best. Doe is de ting
De Fransh man loves: If all your both two daughters
Shew all; all makes but more desire to do.
Speak I no good English, Madamoiselle?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: You no understand me,
Because you tinck I lie. But if you lie
With me, I make you understand me presently.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: This hot-rein'd Mousieur takes 'em for the same.
Strigood would have 'em be I came in time.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: At afternoon we'll have an exercise
Of courtship, Gentlemen. In the Interim,
If you will have to stir the appetite,
A dance before our Ordinary we are for you.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: And we for you Alloun al Egremant Alloun
Monsieur Papillion pour l' honour de France.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: What are your dances chiefly in request.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Good Landlady, bid the Musick be in readinesse.
And then see dinner set upon the table.
We have Sir for Corants,— La Miniard,
La Vemimde, Le Marquesse, Le Holland,
La Brittaine, Le Roy, Le Prince, Le Montague,
The Saraband; the Canaries, La Reverree.
For Galliards, the Sellibrand, the Dolphine,
The new Galliard, the Valette Galliard and lepees,

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: 'Tis all very good Monsieur Papillica Essontes
Mon Amy.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And heark you, Monsieur Strigood, you will be put to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I feare no French flashes. Beare up Cash. If we cannot daunce 'hem of o' their legs, our wenches can,
I warrant thee. Musick be ready.
Gallants, what are you pleased to daunce?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: tells what, &c.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Gentlemen, your dinner stays meat will be cold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And we are hot, 'tis better that take cold then we.
But come, one table for us all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stri. Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I say so too.
But to my self reserve what I will do.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: EPhraim, thou hast made me a man, both without, witnesse this sword and within, witnesse this precious book, which I have gotten almost by heart already.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: But sir, beware you fall not back again Into your childish follies: but go forwards In manly actions: for non progredi est regredi.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I know the meaning of that too, Ephraim. That's once a man and twice a childe. But if I turne childe again, while I have teeth in my head, I'le give Mrs. Blithe leave to dig 'hem out with Sugar-plums, as she almost did these two of 'hem yesterday, with her knuckles. I would they stuck both in her bum for't, till I were married to her, and that shall be shortly, they say, I wo' not turne boy again for that trick.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope you will not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p:
Thou mayest be sure on't Ephraim: for if I would turne boy again, I ha' not wherewithal to set up again. Thou sawest that, assoon as I had tasted the sweetnesse of this delicious book here, I tore and burnt all my ballats, as well the godly as the ungodly. In my conscience as many as might have furnish't three Bartholomew Faires, and then for love of this sword, I broke and did away all my storehouse of tops, gigs, balls, cat and catsticks, pot-guns, key-guns, trunks, tillers, and all; and will I turne boy again canst think? yet I am half sorry, being towards a wife, that I did
not keep 'hem for my children: some money might have been sav'd by't. And that is a manly and a good husbandly consideration, I take it. But hang covetousnesse: There comes not a mouth into the world, but there's meat for t; and if I finde 'em not play games, their mother will finde friends, that shall, for them and her selfe too

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I'm glad to heare such good things to come from you,
And hope that now your judgment's strong enough
To manage my affair. You know my minde, sir.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Amardla Ephraim, 'twill be hard to compasse. For the old Knight will never let me have his Neece, unlesse he have my mother. He meanes to truck for her, though, I confesse, I had rather call thee father then any man, I know, yet I know not how to bring it about, unlesse he marry her first; and then she be weary of him, and take thee afterwards to mend her match. I think it must be so, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Now you flie out again, that's as impossible, as 'tis unlawful.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Within. Negh. Negh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Peace, my mother comes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Where are you childe? Neh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I hear her neighing after me, I'le do all I can for thee, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Look you sonne, what kinde Sir Swithin has sent you. A dancing frog, you would think it were alive, and a ballet of burning the false prophets before they be tried. And another fearful one of the new Antichrist.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Hang bawbles, burn ballets, I am a man, and defie boyes tricks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A sudden change, I pray it be good.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Tell me of toyes? I have a sword: offer me ballets? I have a book. Speak to me of Sir Swithin, I'le talk to you of Ephraim that gave me these blessings; and is fitter to be my father, (so he is) then the foolishest Knight of 'em all.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Blesse my sonne from too much learning. That book has done him no good, I doubt. He talks and looks so wildly o'the sudden.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A ha!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What book is't. Let me see it.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I'le tell you first. It is a book all of Bulls, Jests and Lies Collected by an A. S. Gent. Mother f'sooth, there be such things in it! If you never reade it, it is the rarest book that ever you read in your life. Open it where you will, and you shall learn something. As here now. One refusing to eat Cheese-cakes, was ask't his reason. He told them he lov'd the flesh well, but was afeard of the bones. Then here's the next to't. One asking whence Lobsters were brought: his fellow repli'd, one might easily know their countrey by their coat. They are fetch't from the red sea. Now would I might never eat more of 'hem, as well as I love 'hem, if I know what Cheese-cakes were made of, or from whence Lobsters came before.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is this your book-learning? In troth thou mak'st me laugh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Laugh on, good Mother. And while you are in the merry mood, let me speak a good word for Ephraim. I have a minde f'sooth, because he has made me a man, to make him my father, f'sooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! How now.
How durst you sirrah, move my sonne in this? ha.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is it but so? ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'sooth hear him speak. He can speak Poetry (he sayes) as well as Knight Whimlbie. Speak Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, Faire truth have told
That Queens of old
Have now and then
Married with private men.
A Countesse was no Blusher,
To wed her Usher.
Without remorse
A Lady took her Horse-
Keeper in wedlock. These did wisely know,
Inferiour men best could their work below.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother f'sooth, Is it not fine?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, more then so, I'le further go

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But you shall not, Sirrah. What, what! how now! Is't but up and ride? ha! Out of my doors thou varlet.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I must out too then, mother I am afraid, oh.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Good Neh. be pacified, I'le give him a better answer.
sp.l: But not a word on't now, sweet childe, I pray thee.
Here comes Sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I marry Sir Swithin. This is better then O Madam, O—, when you wash't your handkerchiefs in the suds, and then to wring hem out in Poetry.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p:
My tears with the memory of the dead are all fallen into Lethe; and nothing but joy left in me, sinc my hopes are confirm'd in your lap. And hang
Poetry: I study profit now. Therefore, look you, Madam, here is a draught of my marriage-instrument to your lap.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: His instrument being drawn, I must put up my pipe and be gone.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: And here is another draught for sweet Master Nehemiah, for my Neece Blithes Joincture.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O but she sayes she will not have me.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: When did she say so?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Now, now, she spat the word out of her mouth. And I say, if she ha' not me, you shall whine both your eyes out before you have my mother; and see ne're the worse, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A crosse marriage, or no marriage, I say still.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I say so too, sonne, Sweet boy, be content.

sp.speaker: Whi. Blithe.
sp.p: You spoke well of him behinde his back: and made me think you lov'd him, and would marry him.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Behinde his back, I may do much to please you. But when I look upon him, he turnes my stomack worse then a fool made of soure milk.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Marry Gip, Mrs Queasie, my sonne's as sweet as you, I hope, and as wise as you. And suck't as sweet milk as ever the good Cow your mother gave.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Patience, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope the crosse marriage is crost. This is untoward wooing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Uds so! do you flirt out your unsavoury comparisons upon my sonne?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Flirt not you at me, Madam, lest I flirt your milk-sop under the snotty nose here.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Yes, and I have a sword, and you ha' got ne're a one.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You wo' not will you, ha! Do you flie at him, ha!

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Fear not, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ephraim, save my boy.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Whi
sp.p: She shall not hurt him. Leave her to me, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ever fear'd he was not long-liv'd he was so witty. And now I feare, she will be the death of him. I would not he should marry her for a million.

sp.speaker: Neh
sp.p: Say not so, mother. I love her better and better still.
I never had play-fellow i my life, but we fell out and in agen.
And I must and will marry her, I take my death on't aforehand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O me! he is bewitch't to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Leave all to me, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: As I am to you, I think, Sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Let me alone with her: I'le win her, and he shall wear her, feare not. As I was saying, Madam, she speaks as well of him behinde his back, as your owne heart can wish. And told me she was content to marry him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Behinde his back? did she so?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes truly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Loe you there, mother, Let her marry me behind my back then: And when we are marri'd, I'le make her stick to't before my face, I warrant you; or if she will make back-play. I'le play at nothing but backgammons with her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, Heaven blesse thee, thou art but too good for her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Speak gently, Neece, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Madam, I hope your Ladiship shall finde me too good for him. If e're he has me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ha! say you so?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She meanes in well-doing, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay then, I thank you Mrs. Blithe. Assuring you that you shall be no way so good to him, but I will be as good to you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Agreed again of all hands. But look how she turnes and keeps cut like my Sparrow. She will be my back Sweet-heart still I see, and love me behind.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She is yet raw, and has not much been abroad to see the manners of the time. In which my melancholy has been her main hinderance. But Madam, there is now that is worth all our sight and observation; A new Academy, where they say, the newest and most courtly carriage and behaviour is taught and practised both for young Gentlemen and women. Have you not heard on t?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes Sir Swithin; and that the French tongue is taught there with great alacrity; and my sonne is wish't thither, but soft I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: But let him see it: at least in our company it will embolden him; I mean to carry my Neece thither. I have been a Lover of Arts and Exercises; and know somewhat since my youth. Pray let us spend one houre of this afternoon there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pardon me good sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: But he shall not mother if you love me: for I mean to perfect my dancing there; and to learn French there; For I mean when I am married to travel into France. But I will first be perfect in the tongue I shall learne it the sooner when I am there you know. Pray let us go to th' A comedy, what dee call it?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: The Academy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you so sonne? then come sir Swithin. Come Mrs. Blithe, we will all go.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: I'le wait upon you, though my heart sayes no.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O mine own heart! how near were we both fallen
Into the Gulf of Ruine?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thanks for our delivery!
We were upon the brink of main destruction.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Was ever such a Friend as this mine Vncle?
Pretending us his children too, and call'd us daughters
To those he bargain'd with to sell our Maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: 'Twas a most damnable practise fie upon him.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And had the Monsieurs been as capable
Of our Virginities, as he was of.
Their moneys, how had we then resisted.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: By Venus (mine own heart) my Gentleman
Came up so close to me, that if my voice
Had not been stronger then mine armes (O me!
I tremble son it yet) I had been vanquish't,

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But did you note the vertue of the Gentlemen?
When they were sensible of our feares and tears,
How gently they desisted and with what humanity,
When they perceiv'd how we had been betrayd,
They pitied our conditions; and woo'd homditly
Our loves in way of marriage. Provided that
Our births and fortunes might no way disparage
Theirs, being free and generous

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I confesse
I love 'hem both so well, that if they prove
(As they pretend they are not) our inferiours
In blood and worth, I would take either of'em.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Troth (mine own heart) 'tis just the same with me.
I care not which I have. And mark a sympathy,
How equally all our affections strike.
We both love them, they both love us alike.
But peace. Cash, though he has done us good service,
Must not know all. How goes it within Cash?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And why Cash pray. Ha' not you chang'd your names
From Joyce and Gabriella to Jane and Frances.
And is not your Uncle Strigood now become
Your father, by the name of Mr. Lightfoot
The nimble dancing Master? And must I still
Carry the name of Cash? and having lost
My nature too, in having no cash left?
(Pox o'the dice) call me Mr. Outlash.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: My father will fetch you home with an Inlash,
One o'these dayes.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: But after you, faire Mistris,
Now to your question for the squares within.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I with the Frenchmen, and my Uncle Strigood.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Your father Lightfoot, you forget agen.
There's a drawn match made: For the Monsieurs
Have ta'ne their money again: And you have still
Your Maidenheads, I hope. But to have heard
The coile they kept, the wrangle, and the stir;
And how the young Blades put the old one to't;
Would ha perplext you more then keeping of
Your Maidenheads from men you love.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: You cannot tell that.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: O how the old man chafes that you would offer
To make your mone to them to move their pity,
And not to make his bargain good; and then
How they put home his basenesse to him; to make sale
Of his own blood and honour in his children.
(They knew they said some parents in their countrey,
After their children were turn'd whores, would share
To live upon the profits, but to sell
Their soules before they were damned, fie; fie, fie, fie).
Till he confest indeed you were none of his.
But children of some friends of his deceast,
Left to his care for breeding; which he had
Plenteously given, and thought it might seem reasonable
To raise his money out of you agen.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: What an old devil is this?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Baser and baser still.
The Monsieurs cri'd, and swore if they could finde
Your Parents were Gentle and vertuous,
Being their first Loves, they would marry you,
To free you from this miserable thraldome.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Brave honest Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Be advis'd though, Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I hope I shall.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Beware of Travellers, many passe abroad
For gallant fellowes that have run their countrey,
For picking pockets.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And some you know at home
For cozening their Masters.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You are pleas'd.
But you have known my love; for Gabriella
Let'hem share her betwixt 'hem. You and I
Made one, may soon make peace with the old man
At home.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O Rogue! I'le tell you more anon Cash.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, Monsieur Papillion.
And Monsieur Galliard, all friends, all friends.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: And agree for me.
Agree poor tout.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Chear up your faces Girles.
'Twas but my trial of your chastity.
And since you have stood firme, I am proud of you.
Trust me, 'twas but to try you.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Wee wee All, but for try. Trimount, trimount.
No more, but all for try: no man can tinck,
But 'twas too very moshe to take two hundred
Crowns for two pusillages, no, no was but
For try: but and she had not squeek and scrash too
Like to do leetel chat, I had Trimount
One, two, tree, five time, for all your try.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: What's past let be forgot. According to
Agreement, Gentlemen, y'are now content
To joyne with us in Academick fellowship,
And for your pastime professe Art and Science,
As we do for our profit: y'are expert,
I finde; and shall winne wonder of our Nation,
To your own much delight out of their follies.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And then for Gamesters, Gentlemen. If you'll play.
I'le bring ye those shall venture money enough.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: We are planted to our wish.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: All very good.
All very good; but I would see thee first.
What Ladies will come here to practise complement.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You are still hot upon the female Monsieur Galliard
Monsieur Papillion here flies over them.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, the newes?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: The old will to't.
As well as the young I see.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: To what Landlady?
sp.stage: He takes her aside. And that while the young men and maids court and confer at tother side.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: To fashion following;
A Reverend Lady
Of fifty five; and a Knight of threescore
And upwards, are come hither to learn fashion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Do you know their names?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, yes: and them; 'tis that
Begets my wonder.
'Tis the Lady Nestlecock, and one Sir Swithin Whimlby.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Wit be merciful unto us.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: The Ladies man's without: who came to know if the house were ready to entertain 'hem; do you know 'em Mr. Lightfoot?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I have heard o'th' Lady. Cash, see if it be Ephraim.
He cannot know thee. Let him not away,
By any meanes, his not return to them may keep 'hem back.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I see him hither.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, is your husband come from ducking.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, overjoy'd with the good sport he has had.
He'll play th' good fellow then. Entreat him Cash.
To help thee, put a cup or two upon
That fellow; and hear'st me, spice his cup,
I mean, grave Ephraims cup with this same powder,
'Twill lay him asleep, and quickly.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I know the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And Landlady, when the Knight and Lady come,
Say we are ready for 'em.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: 'Tis then an absolute contract. I am yours.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And I am yours as firme as faith can binde.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: To which we are de witnesse. Be so for us,
I am her husband, And she is my wife,
Speak you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: 'Fore Heaven, I do acknowledge it,
But sir, the Church must be observ'd,

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: For that.
We'll send for one Minister that shall marry
Us all at once. One kisse till then shall serve.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well done Monsieurs, I no sooner turn
My back, but you are on the Damosels lips.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: A leetel in de honest way will serve,
But he shall know no-ting.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: On with your Masques-Maids,
And take especial heed you blush not through 'hem.
For here are some at hand will put us to't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: 'Tis not my father, nor my Lady Aunt?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I cannot promise you. Be bold and safe.
Beare it out bravely, or our school breaks up
Immediately: and we are broke forever,
Besides, there is no starting.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: That's enough
To make a coward fight, and mine own heart;
We must stand stoutly to't, we lose our loves else.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Well, I am arm'd.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Fall into complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I muse we lost my man thus.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: By your leave, sir.
Are you the Regent of this Academy?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I am sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: And are those of your Assistants.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes sir, and all Professors of Court-discipline,
By the most accurate, yet more familiar
Rules, then have ever yet been taught by any,
For quick instruction both of young and old.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: You promise very fairly. For us old ones,
We know and could have done things in our youth,
Which still we have a minde to: but we leave
The practice to our young ones: Here's a paire
Would faine be at it. We'll pay their admittance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But I'd be glad to see first by your leave,
Some probability of what they shall learn.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And reason good, good Madam. Pray observe there.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Fair star of courtship, my unworthy humble self, a Profest servant to the integrity of beauty, makes this
Clear testimony of your merits, that every eye that sees you,
Owes you his heart for tribute, and that unjustly your beholders live, that live not in your service.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother f'sooth, is not this French?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peace childe. Hear more on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: Noble sir, you are so exactly deserving in the opinion of all righteous judgements, that the least syllable of your faire testimony, is able to re-edifie the ruines of a decayed commendation.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: The best that ever I heard, since I woo'd my Grissel.

sp.speaker: Stri,
sp.p: Was not that a sweet bout, sir?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, it puts me in minde of some sweet bouts I had with one before I married her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: has he married my Sister troe?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: I am forc't to give you over, Madam, you have such a preventing and preoccupying wit in all things.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: That goes like English Mrs. Blithe. I could learn some of that me thinks.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Best tell your mother so; she may rejoyce at it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: There, Lady, was a taste of sweet complement between persons equally affected. May it please you now to let your sonne passe upon this demosel. Who being to her a stranger, and raw (as I imagine) in courtship, shall meet with reprehension, that may be for his instruction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do Neh. speak to her.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Put of your hat and say—.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What! and her masque on?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That was well-said. Why are they mask'd, I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We are commanded it by the policy of wise authority; for feare young heires might fall in love with 'em, and sink their fortunes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You have well satisfied me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What should I say to one I never saw.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: When I was young and bold, I would have said, Lady, you are most auspiciously encountred. And speak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Lady, you are most suspiciously accoutred, I speak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Auspiciously encountred man.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Auspicously encountred woman, I say.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I commiserate your encounter. 'Tis a most hungry, verminous, impoverish't word sir. It seems you are a stranger by't, to the Innovation of courtship.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What should I say to that now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He's a weak scholar forsooth, and would be glad to learn.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: The acknowledgement of his weaknesse is the first greece of gradation to perfection, and his gladnesse the scaling-ladder of resolution.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'sooth, can you teach me a complement to offer you sugar-plums, and eat 'hem my selfe: to save my manners and my plums too?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What a wag it is?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What walking dunghil is this? made of the dust swept from the house of ignorance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! how now, ha? you are a Flapse to terme my sonne so, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O good Madam. This is but school play.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I'le put her by her school-tricks and no only unmask, but unskin her face too, and she come over my heire apparent with such Billingsgate Complements.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Sweet Madam, no harm was meant, and nothing said in earnest: 'Twas meerly but school practice, but to shew the sweet young Gentleman how he might be subject to the scorne of Court, before he be seen in Complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: 'Twas told your Ladiship before, that by reprehension he might finde instruction.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Right Madam; For no Fencer learnes his Science before he receive some hits and knocks too: Oh, I have had many.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, I am satisfied, and pray, that my rash errour may prove pardonable Lady

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Rather let me implore your mercy, Madam—.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
'Tis well, 'tis well Lets hear an Interchange or two now, of complemental acknowledgement of
courtesies past betwixt Ladies, for the edification of this faire one, who seems not yet to have ta'ne notice of us, but looks o' the ground still.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: 'Tis not to finde a fescue, sir, among the Rushes.
To pick out a lesson in your crisse-crosse-row of complement.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sharp and sudden. She has a good wit I see.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ob, good Blithe, observe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Can your poor servant expresse acknowledgement enough, Lady, for favours so incessantly heap't upon her, besides the accumulation of many secret benefits?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: I cannot but admire, Madam, your noble and illustrious Gratitude, that can give beauty to benefits of so low a birth and condition.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: O my Grissel comes to my minde agen, she was the gratefullest woman.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: If such favours, Madam, should passe under an humble name, Honour would grow idle, and a thankful Nature beguil'd of her emploiment.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You'll make my zeale hereafter, too bashful to serve your most curious acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Curious acknowledgement! There was a thrid drawn out.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am hound by many kindnesses, Madam, to celebrate the faire memory of you; as the trouble of your Coach twice in one day, besides those inestimable Jewels, the Monkey and Dormouse your Ladiship sent me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I would you could lend me a sight of 'hem forsooth, I love such things devoutly.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You do but open a privie door to my thankful remembrance, Madam, for the bounty of your Squirrel and Paraquitoe.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Fagh, shut that privie-door.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And shut in the Squirrel and the Paraquitoe to be stifled, shall she? O that I could see hem!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Now Madam, and Sir Knight, Is not this neat and handsom?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Truly, truly, 'tis most admirable pretty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Nay, if you heard our Lectures, saw our
Daunces.
Relish't our Musick and harmonious voices,
Observ'd our Rules for fashion and attire,
Our many exact postures and dimensions,
Fit to be us'd by way of Salutation,
Of courtesie, of honour, of obeisance,
To all degrees of man or womankind,
From the low bent of vassalage, to the head
Of towring Majesty, you should admire.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But do you reade and teach all these to your scholars?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Stand forth, Monsieur Galliard. Stay w'are interrupted.
sp.l: Up maids, and quickly; or 'tis not your Masques
Can keep you undiscover'd. Go, be ready,
With Musick and your voices, when I call to yee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why are we interrupted? pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, it is my naughty Aunt, so 'tis.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No matter, sonne, we'll take no notice of her.
sp.l: I wonder at the boldnesse of the drudge though.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can turne taile too, as well as the great Lady. Hab.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And do so, Mystresse, give her a broad-side.
sp.l: Well-said, we'll make our partie good, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sir, we have heard your Fame; and love your Arts.
And pray that our ambition be excus'd,
Which drew on our Intrusion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: To me and to the place you are all welcom.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And so to all I hope, chiefly to you,
Good Madam Dowager, hoping in good time
I may get good, by doing much good upon you
How likes your Lop my complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you bring your rude companions to affront me? Are you so hot? you stir up your cinders before they be cak't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Still in the Kitchin-dialect.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No ruder then your self, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I brought her, Madam,
sp.l: T' advance my suit to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Will you see me abus'd
Sir Swithin, look to your Neece, the t'other talks to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Kinde merry Gentlemen, Madam, when I was young I would have done the like. Their coming hither, was as ours was to note th' instructions
That are taught here. Pray sir proceed. On with your exercise, that we may all be edified.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We shall do so, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But sir, your Gentlewomen,
sp.l: That past upon our entrance where are they?

sp.speaker: Stri
sp.p: Sir, they were call'd in haste to private practice
sp.l: With some great Ladies in an upper room.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Umh— private practice. Well, I shall know all.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And they being absent, we shall for the present
sp.l: Only deliver by these Gentlemen,
Some heads of Sciences.
A Song, a Daunce, and then
Entreat you take a taste of a collation.
And all most fairly welcome.
The heads of our chief Arts. Your silence, pray you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: The first is the due carriage of the body,
The proper motion of the head, hand, leg,
To every several degree of person,
From the Peasant unto the Potentate;
To your inferiours how and when to use the Nod,
The Hum, the Ha, the Frown, the Smile,
Upon the fit occassion; and to your equals,
The exactest, newest, and familiar motions
Of eye, of hand, of knee, of arme and shoulder,
That are in Garbe, in Congee, Crindge, or Shrug,
In common Courtesie, or Complement,
Lastly, for your Addresses to Superiours.
The Honours, Reverence, or Obeysances,
Proper unto the quality or estate
Of person whatsoever. And so much
For carriage and behaviour. In the next place
You shall have rules for the more graceful wearing
Of your Apparel, with the natural Reasons,
Why some mans hat does better in his hand
Then on his head, and why his coat hangs neater
Upon his elbow, then upon his back,
As also Reasons for Tunes bringing up.
And marriages, together of the fashions
Of man and woman, how his Caller, and her
Black-bag, came on together; how his pocket-comb
To spruce his Perrule, and her Girdle-glasse,
To order her black pashes, came together;
How his walking in the streets without a cloak
And her, without a man came up together,
Of these, and of a hundred more the like.
We shall demonstrate reasons and instructions.
Shall render you most graceful in each fashion.
The next are skills in instruments, song and dancing

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enough, those shall be made familiar to you
By voice and action instantly. A Song there.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Admirable pretty still.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Are these your Gentlewomens voices, sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: They are

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What do you keep 'hem up like Nuns,
To sing and not be seen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Not alwayes sir.
But may it please yee Gentlemen and Ladies,
Now to observe the practice of our feet
In active dancing.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: That came I to learn,
And to speak French, do you think sir, you can bring
My mouth to handle the French tongue handsomly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He's apt to learn, sir, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Yes. I shall bring his Mout to it. But his Mont is yet a leetel too wide. But he shall have some of de water datde woman use for anoderting, to bring it better together, and he shall speak like de Fransh Lady.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray sir, if you can like the Ladies daughter of Paris properlie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. thou knowest the way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder sir, 'Mongst all your Arts and Sciences
You have so little judgement in a face,
Does his mouth appear wide to you? what false glasse
Are your eyes made of?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What you mean?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, friend.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Pray sir take no offence. Here was none meant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Slander is no offence then. He has injur'd,
By breathing an aspersion on that face,
The life of beauty, and the soule of sweetnesse.
Wide mouth Y—.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Begar Monsieur, you shall no point out mouth,
No, nor out-face the Frensh man with your great Bull-beef, and Mustard English looks.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, gentle Val. forbear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le stop.
This mouth that knowingly sayes he dares except
Against a tittle of his face or person.
But as he is an ignorant stranger, and
I must respect the company. I forbear.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: However sir, I can but thank your love in 't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now it works in her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pardon my plainnesse, Madam.
I never was so ta'ne with Masculine beauty.
And till I winne a woman that is like him,
Or has been like him, I can but languish.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They told me I was like him, when I was younger.
And let me tell you y'are a comely Gentleman.
And be you but as honest as y'are handsom, you deserve well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Umh, 'tis a hard matter to bring those ends together.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother f'sooth. Here's a man now for you to make my father!
Beyond the Knight or Ephraim!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Were I free from the old Knight, I could look well upon him.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Come servant, come away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By no meanes, Mystresse, I do but sooth her up to jeare her for vou.
If you out-stay her not, you lose your honour.
She'll brag she has out-look't you. If you start.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Nay, and she go to that, I hope I can,
Look as ill favouredly as her selfe, or a better
Woman then she, and stay in spight of her, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, Mystris, Madam shall I tell you.
But I would pray you not to storme, but laugh at it.
She sayes you are no match for me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And knowing I aim at none but some great widow.
Tells me she knows her husband's but short-liv'd.
I fear she means to break his heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No words, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Yet more whispering.
Pray Madam let us go. Neece come away,
For I fear Madam, as you wisely doubted,
This is no companie for us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, I hope.
I am not yet so tied, but I may safelie
Use my own freedom, I'le go when I please.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: O Grissel, Grissel, when would'st thou have said so?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Loves power, I hope, hath wonne on destinie,
T' appoint this day for my delivery.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir Swithin,— Ladies— we have yet
Dauncing to come, and a Collation promis'd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes Gallants, now w' are readie, we but stayed for this fourth man here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Camelion.
Where is your wife? I hope your je lousie.
Locks her not up.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish Honi soit. I hate it.
No, she has been preparing of a banquet,
Which now is ready for you, worthy Mr. Lightfoot,
And your faire company; jealousie I defie
The base horne Ague, Mr. Askal I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What does he call you? Rascal?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Askal Madam.
My name is Askal. But the R in Master
Runs into so, that sometimes it sounds doubtful.
I must be Knighted, Euphoniae gratia.
Sir Valentine Askal will come fairly off.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now note me Mr. Askal, and tell me if ever jealous man came so lightly off.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Sir, your collation stayes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Gallants and Ladies
Wilt please you enter.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, of all sides.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: INhospitable! 'tis inhumane, past
The cruelty of infidels.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou speak'st
But thine own barbarous cruelty, hollow Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Abominable hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Cunning Villain.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Fie Gentlemen, forbear this unknown language.
And either speak to others understanding,
If you speak Justice:

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Give me then my sonne.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Thou hast thy sonne, give me my sonne and daughter.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, if you'll not hear each other, yet both hear me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I pray Captain speak.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You had his sonne to foster; he your daughter.
You faithfully affirme you sent his sonne
For England a moneth since.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: And mine own with him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You have confest you put away his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And mine own with her, through her disobeence.
But 'twas upon advertisement by letter,
That he had first cast off my sonne to an
Untimely death.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Some Villain forg'd that letter,
And let me tell you sir, though in your house,
Lafoy's an honest and a temperate man.
You are rash and unadvis'd, what Lafoy speaks
I will maintain for truth: what you have done
I wish you could make good; But I may fear
You are mark't out by your own wilfulnesse,
The subject of much woe and sad misfortune.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not what I am; but did you know
The number, and the weight of my afflictions,
You could not chide me thus without some pity.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Indeed I pity you, and now y'are calme,
Know that Lafoy sent his sonne over with yours,
And but for some affaires he had with me,
I'th Isle of Wight he had embarqu'd himself
With them, and brought hem to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There's hope then yet
That my boy lives.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And is come over feare not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You comfort me, and now Lafoy y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: But to what comfort, having lost my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Lost or lost not, mine's with her. And I
purpose now to be sad no longer. For I think
I ha' lost my wife too, there's a second comfort.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Take an example here Monsieur Lafoy,
And shake of sadnesse; mirth may come unlook't for.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I ha' lost a sonne too, a wilde roaring Lad,
About this town. And if I finde not him,
I doubt not I shall finde, that he has spent me
A hundred pound since I last heard of him.
By the way sir, I sent you a bill of change
Last moneth, to pay a hundred pieces for me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Twas paid. I have your bill for my discharge.
How now?
Ha' you found your Mystresse.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nor tidings of her, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She has found then some good exercise, I doubt not.
That holds her so.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, there's a Gentleman
Craves instant speech with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Who? or whence comes he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He will be known to none before he sees you.
And, when you see him, he sayes he thinks you'll know him.
He's a brave gallant, one o'the Alamodes,
Nothing but French all over.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fetch him me quickly,
It is my sonne. Grammercie mine own heart,
That wast not light so suddenlie for nothing,
Pray Gentlemen, who e're you see, name no man
To me, unlesse I ask you. He comes, he comes.
I'm grown a proper man. Heaven make me thankful.
Just such a spark was I at two and twenty,
Set cloathes and fashion by. He thinks to try
If I can know him now. But there I'le fit him.
With me sir is your businesse?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I presume
You do not know me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: As well as he that got him.
Pray Gentlemen keep your countenances. Not know you sir?
'Tis like I may have known you here to fore,
But cannot readily collect; perhaps
You are much chang'd by Travel, Time, and Bravery,
Since I last saw you. There he may finde.
I partly guesse, but will not know him yet.
Good Geutlemen say nothing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What ailes he troe.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: He knowes me, I feare, too soon. If now my plot faile, and he have a Counterplot upon me. I am laid up.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Do you not know me yet sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Know you, or know you not sir, what's your businesse.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You sometimes had a sonne sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes to me.
I had sir. But I hear he's slain in France.
And farewel he. Mark how I handle him.
And what sir of my sonne?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: He's dead you say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I mufe the Knave askes me not blessing though.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: But to supplie his losse you have a daughter
That may endear a sonne, sir, to your comfort.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whither now flies he trow! Sir, do you know her.
Or where to finde her?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: First upon my knees
Let me implore your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes home: And I can hold no longer.
My blessing boy, thou meanest. Take it, and welcome
To a glad father. Rise, and let my teares,
If joy confirm thy welcom.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I may not rise yet sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No? why? what hast thou done? where's young Lafoy?
My true friends sonne here? whom I now must lock
Up in these armes, amidst a thousand welcomes.
Where's the young man?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I know not who you mean sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Distract me not.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: I feare you are destraught.
I know not him. How should he know my son.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let me look nearer.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Sir, I am your Prentice.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whow— whow, whow, who— my Thiese and Runaway.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Prav sir afford me hearing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, your cause
Requires a Judges hearing.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I have put me
Into your hands, and not without much hope,
To gaine your pardon, and your daughters love.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis roundly spoken. Gentlemen, I'le tell you.
This gallant youth, has gallanted away
A thousand pound of mine.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: For your advantage sir: For
By this way
Of Gallantry, as you call it, I have travell'd
Through the Resorts and Haunts publike and private
Of all the Gallants in the Town. In brief
I have found your daughter, where she had been lost
For ever in your brother Strigoods hands.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Canst bring me thither?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Is my daughter with her?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Madam Gabriella, the French Damsel's there.
And others, men and women, whom you'll know when you come there.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Good sir, lets hasten thither.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You'll aid me, sirs?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes, with our lives and fortune.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be fearlesse Lady, and upon my life,
Honour, and faith; you are secure from danger.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Sir, I have put me in your hands you see
So liberally that I may feare to suffer,
If not a censure, yet a supposition
Of too much easinesse, in being led
So suddenly so farre towards your desire.
But my opinion of your noblenesse
Joyn'd with your Protestation, pleads my pardon
At least it may, the wretchednesse considered,
To which I was enthrall'd.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: It is not more my love
Unto your vertue, and your faire endowments.
Then pity in me labours your release.
Nor is it rather to enrich my self.
Then to save you from so immense a danger,
As you had fallen into by yielding under
Your Uncles weaknesse in so fond a match.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Blesse me from being fool-clog'd.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now you are free.
If you can think your self so, and but yield
Unto my present Counsel.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do so Lady
Before you are mist within. Here is the Closet,
And here's the Key in your own hands, And presently I'le fetch a Priest.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You see
I still deal fairlie w'ye; and give you power
To keep guard on your self.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: And yet I yield
My self your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In: some body comes.
She will be yours. And let me tell you, sir,
I wish you as much joy with her, as I
Have with my Cock.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You have befriended me
In this good enterprise: And one good turne
Requires another. And now for that I told you,
Touching your wife, your Cock you so rejoyce in.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas. alas, good Gentlemen, you would fain
Ha' me be jealous. Honi soit, y'are short.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Stand by and observe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you begin to boggle,
And when I send for twenty pieces, do you
Send me but ten?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay mark.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray,
What have I had in all by your account.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: At several times, you have had fifty pounds of my poor husbands money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What's that to the free pleasure of my body
Which must afford you sweet and lustie payment?
You froward Monkey. But perhaps you ha' got
Some new-found Horn-maker, that you may think,
Deserves your husbands money better, for
Doing his Journey-work, one o'the Monsieurs,
Or both perhaps i'th' house here under's Antlers,
It must be so, why else of all the town,
Must I be one o'th' last that must take notice
Of your new College here, your brazen face College
Of feates and fine fagaries? do you grow weary of me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Do you grow wilde? speak lower, do you mean to undo me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will tother fifty pound undo thee, I have lost
All that I had within among your Monsieurs.
And you must yield supply, or lose a friend
Of me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What a way would so much money have gone
In betts at the ducking pond?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will no lesse serve your turn then fifty?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No lesse. All makes (you know) but a just hundred.
And there I'le stick; and stick close to thee too,
Else all flies open. What care I who knows
Your credits breach, when you respect not mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis too well known already; All's too open.
My house, my purse, my wife, and all's too open.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: O me, undone.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Was ever loving husband
So much abusd?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Enquire among your neighbours.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be patient man.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O thou close whore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take heed, sir, what you say.
Eene now you said she was too open, sir.
Y'are in two tales already.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I feare he's mad
Or jealous, which is worse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pish, Honi soit.
He jealous, he defies it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do you deride me?
Sir, you can witnesse with me, he confest
Receipt of fifty pounds my wife has lent him,
(False woman that she is) for Horn-making,
Job Journey-work.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I know.
(At least I think) I am deceiv'd in both.
My money and thy honesty, but the Lawes
In both shall do me right, or all shall flie for't.
I'le instantly to councel.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Hear me first.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: By all meanes hear her first. Pray grant her that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I dare not look on her, lest I be tempted
To yield unto my shame and my undoing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you not heare your Cock, your Nansie,
Nanny Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Time was you would not ha' denied me that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nor any thing, if my Cock had but stood upon't.
Such was my love, but now,

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But now y'are jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Have I not cause?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here's tother fifty pieces, take 'hem sir.
They are full weight, and truly told.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Brave wench.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: If you will law, sir, you shall law for something.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope she'll humble him so,
That he shall keep our chamber-door for us,
While we get boyes for him. A dainty Rogue,
She tempts me strongly now. Would she would call me
About it presently.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That money sir
May serve to countenance you among the Gamesters
Within, that blew you up. The Lady widow
May think the better of your credit too,
Being so good i'th' house.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le streight amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Councel me not sir. All my joyes are gone.
I cannot think now what a ducking pond
Can be good for, except to drown me in't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Alas, poor man, I was in this too busie.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Stay, you shall promise me before my husband,
That you will never more attempt my chastity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That bargaine's yet to make. Though before him
I may say much, I will not stand to that
For all the wealth he has.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You shall protest
Then, fairly, as you are a Gentleman
You never have enjoy'd me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I like that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, no, I cannot safely, for in that
I shall surrender up my interest
In's house; and he may warne me out on't. No,
Take heed o' that. 'Tis not his tother hundred
Shall make me slip that hold.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am lost again.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What a bold thief is this! Pray heare me, sir.
You may remember that I ask't you once
What Countreyman you were.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, when you first cast your good liking on me, and I told you.
sp.l: O'th' Isle of Wight: And what o' that?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you
Call Captain Hardyman, their father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You wrong me basely, to say I call him any thing; for he gives me nothing.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You wrong him basely. Look you, Can you reade.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I had done ill to venter (as I ha' done)
On Salisbury plain else. Hah, what's here
sp.p: That daughter, I sent you order to receive for me an hundred pounds. If you finde that your brother the Spendthrift Val. Askal, (Zookes that I) be in any want, furnish him according to your own discretion.
sp.l: I am Val. Askal, where's the money? My hundred
pound, ha' you't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: It seems a Sister of yours had it.
Ha' you a sister?

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: He had a daughter by my mother, but
He plac'd her out a childe, I know not where
Where's that young whore trow? Hannah I think
her name was. Hang me if I know directly.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My wives name's Hannah, sir.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I am that sister, brother, but no whore.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. your brags to make men think you lay with her.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You have your hundred pound sir. Look you, husband.
This is my fathers letter which you wrote on.
That which you dar'd the devil and Clerks to counterfeit, reade your own hand.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Honi soit qui maly pense.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I must admire this woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do'st think I did not know thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: No sir, nor would I that you should,
Till I had foil'd you in your course,
And had my will to make my husband jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Cock, my Cock again, my Nanny cock,
Cock-all my Cock-a-hoop, I am overjoy'd,
See, see thy father too.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the woman.
To whom I paid your money.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis my daughter—.
My blessing on you.— What are you here too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ask you blessing too. Your hundred pound Has bound me to't. Heaven blesse you, Here's halfe one still, yes, and the better halfe, for tother's spent.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: O y'are a great good husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would be one. And here's a good rich widow
Now in the house, your countenance may help me,
My Sister and my Brother both can tell you,
How orderly and civilly I live.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O wag.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis like sir, I shall prove your Furtherer.
What is she?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That Merchants Sister, and a Lady sir.
I would not have him heare.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: Well talk aside then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In that I'm partly satisfied.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I love you sir,
And waited on your wife but as your Spie,
For feare he might have led her to more folly.

sp.speaker: Mat:
sp.l: But saw you not two such Damsels here?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Here are
Some in the house that would not be seen by us.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Because they thought you'd know 'hem.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And if that
Old fellow be your brother Strigood, tis most strange

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You know not him here do you?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No not I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis my man Cash.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Most wonderful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We shall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Pray haste sir, to discovery: I would faine
Once see my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would see a little
The fashions o'the house first.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Pray obscure
Your selves in that by room there, where you may
See and hear all that passes, nor can any
Passe out o'th' house without your notice.
The Gentlemen and I will mix again
With the Society, if they please.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Agreed.
Within Strigood. Where are you Gent'emen?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Come away Val.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is not that the Hell-hounds voice?

sp.speaker: Cash
sp.l: Yes, 'tis your brother.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good Captain go with us upon discovery.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I'le seat you to see all, and be unseen.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do so good Cock. Do so now sir, I'le fetch the Priest.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, you have lost such sport, the
Lady
And Merchants wife have been by th' eares.

sp.speaker: Cash
sp.l: Could not
The old Knight part 'hem?

sp.speaker: Stri
sp.l: He has done his best,
And almost lost his eyes in the adventure
Betwixt the Furies tallons.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But are they friends agen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And deep in complement.
Our school affords no such in act or language.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sister, Indeed I am too much your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray Madam let me serve you truly truly.
I'le be your servant for a yeare and a day

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed you wrong your self, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am your servants servant, and will serve
Under your Ladiships Cook to do you service.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed you may not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If I may not be
Accepted for your houshold servant, let me
Become your Chare-woman, in any office
From Cupboard to (lose-stool, I can do all
To do your Ladiship service.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: This now savours of Complement indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: In sooth, 'tis sooth, forsooth the tale I tell you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Well acted mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Y'are too obsequious
Good gentle Sister.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am short of good.
Gentle I grant I am, for I bite no body,
Command me then sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And very well acted Nant.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am no Pope, for your sake would I were.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your courtesie o'recomes me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O not so.
I wish it could forsooth, would it were better for you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Exceeding well acted o'both sides.
Mother and Aunt f'sooth, Amardla you have done't
Better then the two School-Mystresses to day
Could do their Whatshicomes, their Complements
I think you call 'hem. But I ha' lost my Mystresse
To complement withal. Mrs. Blithe Tripshort
Has out-strip't me, Amardla that she has.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where's her wise Uncle should ha' look't to her.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: He's crying all about the house for her,
But cannot finde her. How shall I have her now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou shalt not have her boy, she's naught.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Then he's
Naught too. You sha'nt have him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor will, I feare not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Think of the Gentleman, mother that out-fac'd
The Frenchman for me. I would you had a thousand such in France now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: God-a-mercy boy.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Peace, hear a little more.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sir; come away.
I have found a carelesse Curate, that has nothing but a bare Coat too loose shall chopt't up presently. And give him but a piece, he'll fear no Cannon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I am bound to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Whither goes he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No matter, let him go t'untrusse perhaps.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I say she is i'th house.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's gone, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's flowen out of a window, or chimney-top then.
I'm sure I wrtch't the door with epen eyes
E're since you entred, as my Lady charg'd me,
Lest her childe might slip out to play i th' street.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And I am here you see. He cannot see
He has no more eyes then a sucking pig,
And yet he weeps like a roasted one.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I am abus'd,
And render me my Neece,
You have stolne her for your sonne.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My sonne defies her,
As I do you, old whining wither'd fellow,
That has no moisture in him but for teares.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That is my Cue. A young well govern'd man
Were fitter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Where have you been servant?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I speak to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My Lady, I think you said.
Are you so stout sir, hah?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I rather think he playes the cunning hypocrite
With his false teares, and packt her hence himself

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My Lady mindes you not, and I can learn
To give you a broad side too.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, that cannot be, for I have seen
All that went out, or came into the house▪
Since you. Here came a Church man in ere while.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A Churchman! then I feare she's closely married unto her wo and mine.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Perhaps to me.
Behinde my back you said she would do so.
And before him came in your brother Matchil.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My brother, who her husband?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Yes, with others.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My husband, I think you said What a foule house these washing dayes make?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no Jest Now Ladies let me tell you,
And sad Sir Swithin; pray lend all your eares.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Cash, we are betray'd Cash if we be not nimble.
I smell a Fox. Hy thee up quickly Cash,
And hurry down the wenches We'll make bold with
My Ladies Coach to hurry us away.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But not too fast, Go sir, fetch down the wenches.
Thou shamelesse Reprobate. Doest thou hang thy head now?
I'le take a course to hang the rest o'thee.
Your Ladiships well met at the new school.
So is your Chare-woman. Ha' you profited
By the devils doctrine here? you weep sin Swithin
For the iniquity of the times.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: You mean
His Neece, pray Vncle did you meet her,
She's gone away too, after my Cousin Joyce,
And the French maid, I think, she is here agen.
Amardla, wipe your eyes, and look Sir Swithin,
The tother honest Gentleman has found her.
And let him take her for his paines for me.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I thank your love. But sir, 'tis your consent
We only seek.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir Swithin, let 'em have it,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman I would have spoke for:
In birth, in meanes, in person every way
Deserving her. Take him upon my word.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And Madam, since you stick but upon Joyncture,
Having heard lately well of his husbandry.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Thank a good sister, sir.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: I will secure you
Three hundred pounds a year, your brother knows me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: With make good his word. Agree by your selves.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Upon these termes, 'tis like we shall agree.
Sir Swithin are you pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Pleas'd or displeas'd.
It seems they are married.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, I assure you,
I saw their hands joyn'd, and I heard 'hem both
Answer the Priest.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I will no longer whine.
Heaven give you joy, As y'are your owne, y'are mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There are more weddings i'th' house, your daughters,
Are linck't by this time to the two young Frenchmen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: His daughters? ours I fear? what French? where are they?
sp.stage: Enter Cash, two sonne's, Joy, Gab.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Here sir, undone I feare.

sp.speaker: Mat,
sp.l: What are you married.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Jun. Sir, she is mine, I must and will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. And she is mine.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: This is your sonne. And this
Is mine.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is your daughter. And this mine. Each married to her brother.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. Mon Pere Je desire vestre Benediction Jour pour moy & ma femme.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: You are lost children all, was ever thread
By fate so crossely spun, so crossely wed?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not how to Blesse you, or to look
On your incestuous eyes.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. What is dat Incest,
We have commit noting, we have no time,
Since we were marry for so much as kisse,
Begar no point so much as but one kisse.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Be not dismay'd. These marriages are none.
The errour of the persons nullifies
The verbal ceremony; and 'tis well
They past not unto further rites: I'le finde
A lawful way to clear all this. And then
As you and they consent, they shall exchange
And marry in due order.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. Sir I tanck you.
You'ave speak very well. And we shall make.
De exshange presently. A new exchange,
De new Exshange indeed, for de husbands
To shange the wifes before they can be wearie.
Prenez mon frere, la voici la 'une pour lautre.
Dere, is one for anoder:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Is each party
Agreed, and so content?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: J. Gab. We are.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: And we.

sp.speaker: Laf. Ju.
sp.l: Wee wee, I ensuis tresbien contult.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ja.
sp.l: Provided that we have our fathers leaves and councels.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Can you seek fathers leaves or councels now,
That have run from 'hem in your disobedience,
Into the snares of hell: too farre I fear
To be releast. O hell-bred Villain.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Your brother o' one side.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ju.
sp.l: Lend but a patient care.
And by my hopes of your desired pardon
I'le quit you of your feare. 'Tis true, my duty
At my Arrival should have wing'd me to you.
But hearing of your late, ill talk't on marriage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O that root of mischief,
And of my Sisters flight as loth to appear to you,
As to presume a welcom; I was curious
First to observe the Town, and taste the newes;
When more by Providence then accident,
Here we made choice of lodging, saw and lik't
The practices of the Society,
Until this wicked man; (who still presumes
To call you brother,) finding us youthful strangers,
And (as he might suppose) wanton—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He made
A bargain with you for their Maiden heads.

sp.speaker: Cash
sp.l: told me that, and how that hellish purpose
Was vertuously declin'd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O counterfeit Cash.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But must you therefore, knowing whose sons you were.
Marry you knew not whom.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ju.
sp.l: Pardon me, sir.
Our loves were noble, and by due enquirie,
Fetch't from each others faithful breast, the knowledge
Of each other.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What! and marry then
Each his own Sister? Riddle me not to death.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ju.
sp.l: Sir, I have done. And now that I have said
The worst that might have hapned by his practice,
To make his shame or his repentance greater,
Who only was my aim. We are not married,
None of us all are married one to other.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No, I assure you sir. Howere I li'd
At their request, (small matter for a friend)
I saw all the hurt the Priest did here to day.
That was upon them two there.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You shall be then: And so take hands in earnest.
Is't not a double Match Lafoy?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Without
All manner of condition I consent.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am full of joy.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: O can you pardon me sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good boy, good boy. I know not how a City
Could stand without such Prentices. And hope
This wants few such. But what canst thou now say
Brother, o' one side for thy selfe. Speak quickly,
While the good humour holds me to be friends
With all the world: yet yonder's one lies heavy
Athwart my stomack.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Y'are full of joy you say.
And I say had it been within my power,
To have broke your heart, I had don't. Therefore in me
Be comforted and love me; for I finde
I have no power to hurt you, and will therefore
Attempt no further.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Brotherly spoke in troth.
And worthily worth an hundred mark a month,
Shall ha't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Know then into the bargain, that
I forg'd the letter that suggeited to you
My Nephews death, in hope of means that way.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Honestly said again. Now what say you?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I say that I am humbled on my knees.
I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: All's too well me thinks.
But heark, before you break up school, lets have
One frisk, one fling now, one cariering dance,
And then pack up.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed, Agreed, Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Play then Les tous ensembles.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: That's the French name on't, Uncle, 'tis in Dutch
call'd All-to-mall; and I call it in English.
Omnium Gatherum, 'tis the daintiest daunce.
We had it here to day: I and my mother,
My Aunt and all can daunce in't, as well as the best.
With every one in their own footing. Now observe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You have done well. Now pray lets break up school.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: But yet not break up house. My sonne and daughter.
Have given me power to call their Supper mine.
To which I'le give you welcome, Ale and Wine.
sp.stage: Deus dedit his quoque finem, laus Deo.
